text: The Lord spoke to Moses in the tent of meeting in the Desert of Sinai on the first day of the second month of the second year after the Israelites came out of Egypt. He said:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take a census of the whole Israelite community by their clans and families, listing every man by name, one by one.
speaker: Narrator

text: You and Aaron are to count according to their divisions all the men in Israel who are twenty years old or more and able to serve in the army.
speaker: Narrator

text: One man from each tribe, each of them the head of his family, is to help you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the names of the men who are to assist you:
from Reuben, Elizur son of Shedeur;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Simeon, Shelumiel son of Zurishaddai;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Judah, Nahshon son of Amminadab;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Issachar, Nethanel son of Zuar;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Zebulun, Eliab son of Helon;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: from Benjamin, Abidan son of Gideoni;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Dan, Ahiezer son of Ammishaddai;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Asher, Pagiel son of Okran;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Gad, Eliasaph son of Deuel;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Naphtali, Ahira son of Enan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the men appointed from the community, the leaders of their ancestral tribes. They were the heads of the clans of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron took these men whose names had been specified,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they called the whole community together on the first day of the second month. The people registered their ancestry by their clans and families, and the men twenty years old or more were listed by name, one by one,
speaker: Narrator

text: as the Lord commanded Moses. And so he counted them in the Desert of Sinai:
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the descendants of Reuben the firstborn son of Israel:
All the men twenty years old or more who were able to serve in the army were listed by name, one by one, according to the records of their clans and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number from the tribe of Reuben was 46,500.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the descendants of Simeon:
All the men twenty years old or more who were able to serve in the army were counted and listed by name, one by one, according to the records of their clans and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number from the tribe of Simeon was 59,300.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the descendants of Gad:
All the men twenty years old or more who were able to serve in the army were listed by name, according to the records of their clans and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number from the tribe of Gad was 45,650.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the descendants of Judah:
All the men twenty years old or more who were able to serve in the army were listed by name, according to the records of their clans and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number from the tribe of Judah was 74,600.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the descendants of Issachar:
All the men twenty years old or more who were able to serve in the army were listed by name, according to the records of their clans and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number from the tribe of Issachar was 54,400.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the descendants of Zebulun:
All the men twenty years old or more who were able to serve in the army were listed by name, according to the records of their clans and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number from the tribe of Zebulun was 57,400.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the sons of Joseph:
From the descendants of Ephraim:
All the men twenty years old or more who were able to serve in the army were listed by name, according to the records of their clans and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number from the tribe of Ephraim was 40,500.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the descendants of Manasseh:
All the men twenty years old or more who were able to serve in the army were listed by name, according to the records of their clans and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number from the tribe of Manasseh was 32,200.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the descendants of Benjamin:
All the men twenty years old or more who were able to serve in the army were listed by name, according to the records of their clans and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number from the tribe of Benjamin was 35,400.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the descendants of Dan:
All the men twenty years old or more who were able to serve in the army were listed by name, according to the records of their clans and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number from the tribe of Dan was 62,700.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the descendants of Asher:
All the men twenty years old or more who were able to serve in the army were listed by name, according to the records of their clans and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number from the tribe of Asher was 41,500.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the descendants of Naphtali:
All the men twenty years old or more who were able to serve in the army were listed by name, according to the records of their clans and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number from the tribe of Naphtali was 53,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the men counted by Moses and Aaron and the twelve leaders of Israel, each one representing his family.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Israelites twenty years old or more who were able to serve in Israel’s army were counted according to their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number was 603,550.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ancestral tribe of the Levites, however, was not counted along with the others.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord had said to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not count the tribe of Levi or include them in the census of the other Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, appoint the Levites to be in charge of the tabernacle of the covenant law—over all its furnishings and everything belonging to it. They are to carry the tabernacle and all its furnishings; they are to take care of it and encamp around it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the tabernacle is to move, the Levites are to take it down, and whenever the tabernacle is to be set up, the Levites shall do it. Anyone else who approaches it is to be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites are to set up their tents by divisions, each of them in their own camp under their standard.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites, however, are to set up their tents around the tabernacle of the covenant law so that my wrath will not fall on the Israelite community. The Levites are to be responsible for the care of the tabernacle of the covenant law.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites did all this just as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron:
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Israelites are to camp around the tent of meeting some distance from it, each of them under their standard and holding the banners of their family.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the east, toward the sunrise, the divisions of the camp of Judah are to encamp under their standard. The leader of the people of Judah is Nahshon son of Amminadab.
speaker: Narrator

text: His division numbers 74,600.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tribe of Issachar will camp next to them. The leader of the people of Issachar is Nethanel son of Zuar.
speaker: Narrator

text: His division numbers 54,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tribe of Zebulun will be next. The leader of the people of Zebulun is Eliab son of Helon.
speaker: Narrator

text: His division numbers 57,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men assigned to the camp of Judah, according to their divisions, number 186,400. They will set out first.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the south will be the divisions of the camp of Reuben under their standard. The leader of the people of Reuben is Elizur son of Shedeur.
speaker: Narrator

text: His division numbers 46,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tribe of Simeon will camp next to them. The leader of the people of Simeon is Shelumiel son of Zurishaddai.
speaker: Narrator

text: His division numbers 59,300.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tribe of Gad will be next. The leader of the people of Gad is Eliasaph son of Deuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: His division numbers 45,650.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men assigned to the camp of Reuben, according to their divisions, number 151,450. They will set out second.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the tent of meeting and the camp of the Levites will set out in the middle of the camps. They will set out in the same order as they encamp, each in their own place under their standard.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the west will be the divisions of the camp of Ephraim under their standard. The leader of the people of Ephraim is Elishama son of Ammihud.
speaker: Narrator

text: His division numbers 40,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tribe of Manasseh will be next to them. The leader of the people of Manasseh is Gamaliel son of Pedahzur.
speaker: Narrator

text: His division numbers 32,200.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tribe of Benjamin will be next. The leader of the people of Benjamin is Abidan son of Gideoni.
speaker: Narrator

text: His division numbers 35,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men assigned to the camp of Ephraim, according to their divisions, number 108,100. They will set out third.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the north will be the divisions of the camp of Dan under their standard. The leader of the people of Dan is Ahiezer son of Ammishaddai.
speaker: Narrator

text: His division numbers 62,700.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tribe of Asher will camp next to them. The leader of the people of Asher is Pagiel son of Okran.
speaker: Narrator

text: His division numbers 41,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tribe of Naphtali will be next. The leader of the people of Naphtali is Ahira son of Enan.
speaker: Narrator

text: His division numbers 53,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men assigned to the camp of Dan number 157,600. They will set out last, under their standards.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the Israelites, counted according to their families. All the men in the camps, by their divisions, number 603,550.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites, however, were not counted along with the other Israelites, as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites did everything the Lord commanded Moses; that is the way they encamped under their standards, and that is the way they set out, each of them with their clan and family.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the account of the family of Aaron and Moses at the time the Lord spoke to Moses at Mount Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: The names of the sons of Aaron were Nadab the firstborn and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those were the names of Aaron’s sons, the anointed priests, who were ordained to serve as priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nadab and Abihu, however, died before the Lord when they made an offering with unauthorized fire before him in the Desert of Sinai. They had no sons, so Eleazar and Ithamar served as priests during the lifetime of their father Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Bring the tribe of Levi and present them to Aaron the priest to assist him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are to perform duties for him and for the whole community at the tent of meeting by doing the work of the tabernacle.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are to take care of all the furnishings of the tent of meeting, fulfilling the obligations of the Israelites by doing the work of the tabernacle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give the Levites to Aaron and his sons; they are the Israelites who are to be given wholly to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Appoint Aaron and his sons to serve as priests; anyone else who approaches the sanctuary is to be put to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord also said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I have taken the Levites from among the Israelites in place of the first male offspring of every Israelite woman. The Levites are mine,
speaker: Narrator

text: for all the firstborn are mine. When I struck down all the firstborn in Egypt, I set apart for myself every firstborn in Israel, whether human or animal. They are to be mine. I am the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses in the Desert of Sinai,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Count the Levites by their families and clans. Count every male a month old or more.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses counted them, as he was commanded by the word of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the names of the sons of Levi:
Gershon, Kohath and Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the names of the Gershonite clans:
Libni and Shimei.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Kohathite clans:
Amram, Izhar, Hebron and Uzziel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Merarite clans:
Mahli and Mushi.
These were the Levite clans, according to their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: To Gershon belonged the clans of the Libnites and Shimeites; these were the Gershonite clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of all the males a month old or more who were counted was 7,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Gershonite clans were to camp on the west, behind the tabernacle.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leader of the families of the Gershonites was Eliasaph son of Lael.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the tent of meeting the Gershonites were responsible for the care of the tabernacle and tent, its coverings, the curtain at the entrance to the tent of meeting,
speaker: Narrator

text: the curtains of the courtyard, the curtain at the entrance to the courtyard surrounding the tabernacle and altar, and the ropes—and everything related to their use.
speaker: Narrator

text: To Kohath belonged the clans of the Amramites, Izharites, Hebronites and Uzzielites; these were the Kohathite clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of all the males a month old or more was 8,600. The Kohathites were responsible for the care of the sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Kohathite clans were to camp on the south side of the tabernacle.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leader of the families of the Kohathite clans was Elizaphan son of Uzziel.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were responsible for the care of the ark, the table, the lampstand, the altars, the articles of the sanctuary used in ministering, the curtain, and everything related to their use.
speaker: Narrator

text: The chief leader of the Levites was Eleazar son of Aaron, the priest. He was appointed over those who were responsible for the care of the sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: To Merari belonged the clans of the Mahlites and the Mushites; these were the Merarite clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of all the males a month old or more who were counted was 6,200.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leader of the families of the Merarite clans was Zuriel son of Abihail; they were to camp on the north side of the tabernacle.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Merarites were appointed to take care of the frames of the tabernacle, its crossbars, posts, bases, all its equipment, and everything related to their use,
speaker: Narrator

text: as well as the posts of the surrounding courtyard with their bases, tent pegs and ropes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron and his sons were to camp to the east of the tabernacle, toward the sunrise, in front of the tent of meeting. They were responsible for the care of the sanctuary on behalf of the Israelites. Anyone else who approached the sanctuary was to be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of Levites counted at the Lord’s command by Moses and Aaron according to their clans, including every male a month old or more, was 22,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Count all the firstborn Israelite males who are a month old or more and make a list of their names.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take the Levites for me in place of all the firstborn of the Israelites, and the livestock of the Levites in place of all the firstborn of the livestock of the Israelites. I am the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses counted all the firstborn of the Israelites, as the Lord commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of firstborn males a month old or more, listed by name, was 22,273.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord also said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take the Levites in place of all the firstborn of Israel, and the livestock of the Levites in place of their livestock. The Levites are to be mine. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: To redeem the 273 firstborn Israelites who exceed the number of the Levites,
speaker: Narrator

text: collect five shekels for each one, according to the sanctuary shekel, which weighs twenty gerahs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give the money for the redemption of the additional Israelites to Aaron and his sons.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses collected the redemption money from those who exceeded the number redeemed by the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the firstborn of the Israelites he collected silver weighing 1,365 shekels, according to the sanctuary shekel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses gave the redemption money to Aaron and his sons, as he was commanded by the word of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take a census of the Kohathite branch of the Levites by their clans and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: Count all the men from thirty to fifty years of age who come to serve in the work at the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the work of the Kohathites at the tent of meeting: the care of the most holy things.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the camp is to move, Aaron and his sons are to go in and take down the shielding curtain and put it over the ark of the covenant law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they are to cover the curtain with a durable leather, spread a cloth of solid blue over that and put the poles in place.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Over the table of the Presence they are to spread a blue cloth and put on it the plates, dishes and bowls, and the jars for drink offerings; the bread that is continually there is to remain on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are to spread a scarlet cloth over them, cover that with the durable leather and put the poles in place.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They are to take a blue cloth and cover the lampstand that is for light, together with its lamps, its wick trimmers and trays, and all its jars for the olive oil used to supply it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they are to wrap it and all its accessories in a covering of the durable leather and put it on a carrying frame.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Over the gold altar they are to spread a blue cloth and cover that with the durable leather and put the poles in place.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They are to take all the articles used for ministering in the sanctuary, wrap them in a blue cloth, cover that with the durable leather and put them on a carrying frame.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They are to remove the ashes from the bronze altar and spread a purple cloth over it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they are to place on it all the utensils used for ministering at the altar, including the firepans, meat forks, shovels and sprinkling bowls. Over it they are to spread a covering of the durable leather and put the poles in place.
speaker: Narrator

text: “After Aaron and his sons have finished covering the holy furnishings and all the holy articles, and when the camp is ready to move, only then are the Kohathites to come and do the carrying. But they must not touch the holy things or they will die. The Kohathites are to carry those things that are in the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Eleazar son of Aaron, the priest, is to have charge of the oil for the light, the fragrant incense, the regular grain offering and the anointing oil. He is to be in charge of the entire tabernacle and everything in it, including its holy furnishings and articles.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “See that the Kohathite tribal clans are not destroyed from among the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: So that they may live and not die when they come near the most holy things, do this for them: Aaron and his sons are to go into the sanctuary and assign to each man his work and what he is to carry.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Kohathites must not go in to look at the holy things, even for a moment, or they will die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take a census also of the Gershonites by their families and clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Count all the men from thirty to fifty years of age who come to serve in the work at the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the service of the Gershonite clans in their carrying and their other work:
speaker: Narrator

text: They are to carry the curtains of the tabernacle, that is, the tent of meeting, its covering and its outer covering of durable leather, the curtains for the entrance to the tent of meeting,
speaker: Narrator

text: the curtains of the courtyard surrounding the tabernacle and altar, the curtain for the entrance to the courtyard, the ropes and all the equipment used in the service of the tent. The Gershonites are to do all that needs to be done with these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: All their service, whether carrying or doing other work, is to be done under the direction of Aaron and his sons. You shall assign to them as their responsibility all they are to carry.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the service of the Gershonite clans at the tent of meeting. Their duties are to be under the direction of Ithamar son of Aaron, the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Count the Merarites by their clans and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: Count all the men from thirty to fifty years of age who come to serve in the work at the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: As part of all their service at the tent, they are to carry the frames of the tabernacle, its crossbars, posts and bases,
speaker: Narrator

text: as well as the posts of the surrounding courtyard with their bases, tent pegs, ropes, all their equipment and everything related to their use. Assign to each man the specific things he is to carry.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the service of the Merarite clans as they work at the tent of meeting under the direction of Ithamar son of Aaron, the priest.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses, Aaron and the leaders of the community counted the Kohathites by their clans and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men from thirty to fifty years of age who came to serve in the work at the tent of meeting,
speaker: Narrator

text: counted by clans, were 2,750.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the total of all those in the Kohathite clans who served at the tent of meeting. Moses and Aaron counted them according to the Lord’s command through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Gershonites were counted by their clans and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men from thirty to fifty years of age who came to serve in the work at the tent of meeting,
speaker: Narrator

text: counted by their clans and families, were 2,630.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the total of those in the Gershonite clans who served at the tent of meeting. Moses and Aaron counted them according to the Lord’s command.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Merarites were counted by their clans and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men from thirty to fifty years of age who came to serve in the work at the tent of meeting,
speaker: Narrator

text: counted by their clans, were 3,200.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the total of those in the Merarite clans. Moses and Aaron counted them according to the Lord’s command through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses, Aaron and the leaders of Israel counted all the Levites by their clans and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men from thirty to fifty years of age who came to do the work of serving and carrying the tent of meeting
speaker: Narrator

text: numbered 8,580.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At the Lord’s command through Moses, each was assigned his work and told what to carry.
Thus they were counted, as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Command the Israelites to send away from the camp anyone who has a defiling skin disease or a discharge of any kind, or who is ceremonially unclean because of a dead body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Send away male and female alike; send them outside the camp so they will not defile their camp, where I dwell among them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites did so; they sent them outside the camp. They did just as the Lord had instructed Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to the Israelites: ‘Any man or woman who wrongs another in any way and so is unfaithful to the Lord is guilty
speaker: Narrator

text: and must confess the sin they have committed. They must make full restitution for the wrong they have done, add a fifth of the value to it and give it all to the person they have wronged.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if that person has no close relative to whom restitution can be made for the wrong, the restitution belongs to the Lord and must be given to the priest, along with the ram with which atonement is made for the wrongdoer.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the sacred contributions the Israelites bring to a priest will belong to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sacred things belong to their owners, but what they give to the priest will belong to the priest.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and say to them: ‘If a man’s wife goes astray and is unfaithful to him
speaker: Narrator

text: so that another man has sexual relations with her, and this is hidden from her husband and her impurity is undetected (since there is no witness against her and she has not been caught in the act),
speaker: Narrator

text: and if feelings of jealousy come over her husband and he suspects his wife and she is impure—or if he is jealous and suspects her even though she is not impure—
speaker: Narrator

text: then he is to take his wife to the priest. He must also take an offering of a tenth of an ephah of barley flour on her behalf. He must not pour olive oil on it or put incense on it, because it is a grain offering for jealousy, a reminder-offering to draw attention to wrongdoing.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘The priest shall bring her and have her stand before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he shall take some holy water in a clay jar and put some dust from the tabernacle floor into the water.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the priest has had the woman stand before the Lord, he shall loosen her hair and place in her hands the reminder-offering, the grain offering for jealousy, while he himself holds the bitter water that brings a curse.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest shall put the woman under oath and say to her, “If no other man has had sexual relations with you and you have not gone astray and become impure while married to your husband, may this bitter water that brings a curse not harm you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you have gone astray while married to your husband and you have made yourself impure by having sexual relations with a man other than your husband”—
speaker: Narrator

text: here the priest is to put the woman under this curse—“may the Lord cause you to become a curse among your people when he makes your womb miscarry and your abdomen swell.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May this water that brings a curse enter your body so that your abdomen swells or your womb miscarries.”
“‘Then the woman is to say, “Amen. So be it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘The priest is to write these curses on a scroll and then wash them off into the bitter water.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall make the woman drink the bitter water that brings a curse, and this water that brings a curse and causes bitter suffering will enter her.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to take from her hands the grain offering for jealousy, wave it before the Lord and bring it to the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is then to take a handful of the grain offering as a memorial offering and burn it on the altar; after that, he is to have the woman drink the water.
speaker: Narrator

text: If she has made herself impure and been unfaithful to her husband, this will be the result: When she is made to drink the water that brings a curse and causes bitter suffering, it will enter her, her abdomen will swell and her womb will miscarry, and she will become a curse.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, the woman has not made herself impure, but is clean, she will be cleared of guilt and will be able to have children.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘This, then, is the law of jealousy when a woman goes astray and makes herself impure while married to her husband,
speaker: Narrator

text: or when feelings of jealousy come over a man because he suspects his wife. The priest is to have her stand before the Lord and is to apply this entire law to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: The husband will be innocent of any wrongdoing, but the woman will bear the consequences of her sin.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and say to them: ‘If a man or woman wants to make a special vow, a vow of dedication to the Lord as a Nazirite,
speaker: Narrator

text: they must abstain from wine and other fermented drink and must not drink vinegar made from wine or other fermented drink. They must not drink grape juice or eat grapes or raisins.
speaker: Narrator

text: As long as they remain under their Nazirite vow, they must not eat anything that comes from the grapevine, not even the seeds or skins.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘During the entire period of their Nazirite vow, no razor may be used on their head. They must be holy until the period of their dedication to the Lord is over; they must let their hair grow long.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Throughout the period of their dedication to the Lord, the Nazirite must not go near a dead body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if their own father or mother or brother or sister dies, they must not make themselves ceremonially unclean on account of them, because the symbol of their dedication to God is on their head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Throughout the period of their dedication, they are consecrated to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If someone dies suddenly in the Nazirite’s presence, thus defiling the hair that symbolizes their dedication, they must shave their head on the seventh day—the day of their cleansing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then on the eighth day they must bring two doves or two young pigeons to the priest at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to offer one as a sin offering and the other as a burnt offering to make atonement for the Nazirite because they sinned by being in the presence of the dead body. That same day they are to consecrate their head again.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must rededicate themselves to the Lord for the same period of dedication and must bring a year-old male lamb as a guilt offering. The previous days do not count, because they became defiled during their period of dedication.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Now this is the law of the Nazirite when the period of their dedication is over. They are to be brought to the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: There they are to present their offerings to the Lord: a year-old male lamb without defect for a burnt offering, a year-old ewe lamb without defect for a sin offering, a ram without defect for a fellowship offering,
speaker: Narrator

text: together with their grain offerings and drink offerings, and a basket of bread made with the finest flour and without yeast—thick loaves with olive oil mixed in, and thin loaves brushed with olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘The priest is to present all these before the Lord and make the sin offering and the burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to present the basket of unleavened bread and is to sacrifice the ram as a fellowship offering to the Lord, together with its grain offering and drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Then at the entrance to the tent of meeting, the Nazirite must shave off the hair that symbolizes their dedication. They are to take the hair and put it in the fire that is under the sacrifice of the fellowship offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘After the Nazirite has shaved off the hair that symbolizes their dedication, the priest is to place in their hands a boiled shoulder of the ram, and one thick loaf and one thin loaf from the basket, both made without yeast.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest shall then wave these before the Lord as a wave offering; they are holy and belong to the priest, together with the breast that was waved and the thigh that was presented. After that, the Nazirite may drink wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘This is the law of the Nazirite who vows offerings to the Lord in accordance with their dedication, in addition to whatever else they can afford. They must fulfill the vows they have made, according to the law of the Nazirite.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell Aaron and his sons, ‘This is how you are to bless the Israelites. Say to them:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘“The Lord bless you
    and keep you;
speaker: Narrator

text:
the Lord make his face shine on you
    and be gracious to you;
speaker: Narrator

text:
the Lord turn his face toward you
    and give you peace.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So they will put my name on the Israelites, and I will bless them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses finished setting up the tabernacle, he anointed and consecrated it and all its furnishings. He also anointed and consecrated the altar and all its utensils.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the leaders of Israel, the heads of families who were the tribal leaders in charge of those who were counted, made offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought as their gifts before the Lord six covered carts and twelve oxen—an ox from each leader and a cart from every two. These they presented before the tabernacle.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Accept these from them, that they may be used in the work at the tent of meeting. Give them to the Levites as each man’s work requires.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses took the carts and oxen and gave them to the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave two carts and four oxen to the Gershonites, as their work required,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he gave four carts and eight oxen to the Merarites, as their work required. They were all under the direction of Ithamar son of Aaron, the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses did not give any to the Kohathites, because they were to carry on their shoulders the holy things, for which they were responsible.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the altar was anointed, the leaders brought their offerings for its dedication and presented them before the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord had said to Moses, “Each day one leader is to bring his offering for the dedication of the altar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who brought his offering on the first day was Nahshon son of Amminadab of the tribe of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: His offering was one silver plate weighing a hundred and thirty shekels and one silver sprinkling bowl weighing seventy shekels, both according to the sanctuary shekel, each filled with the finest flour mixed with olive oil as a grain offering;
speaker: Narrator

text: one gold dish weighing ten shekels, filled with incense;
speaker: Narrator

text: one young bull, one ram and one male lamb a year old for a burnt offering;
speaker: Narrator

text: one male goat for a sin offering;
speaker: Narrator

text: and two oxen, five rams, five male goats and five male lambs a year old to be sacrificed as a fellowship offering. This was the offering of Nahshon son of Amminadab.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the second day Nethanel son of Zuar, the leader of Issachar, brought his offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the twelfth day Ahira son of Enan, the leader of the people of Naphtali, brought his offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: His offering was one silver plate weighing a hundred and thirty shekels and one silver sprinkling bowl weighing seventy shekels, both according to the sanctuary shekel, each filled with the finest flour mixed with olive oil as a grain offering;
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: and two oxen, five rams, five male goats and five male lambs a year old to be sacrificed as a fellowship offering. This was the offering of Ahira son of Enan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the offerings of the Israelite leaders for the dedication of the altar when it was anointed: twelve silver plates, twelve silver sprinkling bowls and twelve gold dishes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each silver plate weighed a hundred and thirty shekels, and each sprinkling bowl seventy shekels. Altogether, the silver dishes weighed two thousand four hundred shekels, according to the sanctuary shekel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The twelve gold dishes filled with incense weighed ten shekels each, according to the sanctuary shekel. Altogether, the gold dishes weighed a hundred and twenty shekels.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of animals for the burnt offering came to twelve young bulls, twelve rams and twelve male lambs a year old, together with their grain offering. Twelve male goats were used for the sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of animals for the sacrifice of the fellowship offering came to twenty-four oxen, sixty rams, sixty male goats and sixty male lambs a year old. These were the offerings for the dedication of the altar after it was anointed.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses entered the tent of meeting to speak with the Lord, he heard the voice speaking to him from between the two cherubim above the atonement cover on the ark of the covenant law. In this way the Lord spoke to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to Aaron and say to him, ‘When you set up the lamps, see that all seven light up the area in front of the lampstand.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron did so; he set up the lamps so that they faced forward on the lampstand, just as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is how the lampstand was made: It was made of hammered gold—from its base to its blossoms. The lampstand was made exactly like the pattern the Lord had shown Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take the Levites from among all the Israelites and make them ceremonially clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: To purify them, do this: Sprinkle the water of cleansing on them; then have them shave their whole bodies and wash their clothes. And so they will purify themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have them take a young bull with its grain offering of the finest flour mixed with olive oil; then you are to take a second young bull for a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring the Levites to the front of the tent of meeting and assemble the whole Israelite community.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to bring the Levites before the Lord, and the Israelites are to lay their hands on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron is to present the Levites before the Lord as a wave offering from the Israelites, so that they may be ready to do the work of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the Levites are to lay their hands on the heads of the bulls, using one for a sin offering to the Lord and the other for a burnt offering, to make atonement for the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have the Levites stand in front of Aaron and his sons and then present them as a wave offering to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way you are to set the Levites apart from the other Israelites, and the Levites will be mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: “After you have purified the Levites and presented them as a wave offering, they are to come to do their work at the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are the Israelites who are to be given wholly to me. I have taken them as my own in place of the firstborn, the first male offspring from every Israelite woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every firstborn male in Israel, whether human or animal, is mine. When I struck down all the firstborn in Egypt, I set them apart for myself.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I have taken the Levites in place of all the firstborn sons in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: From among all the Israelites, I have given the Levites as gifts to Aaron and his sons to do the work at the tent of meeting on behalf of the Israelites and to make atonement for them so that no plague will strike the Israelites when they go near the sanctuary.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses, Aaron and the whole Israelite community did with the Levites just as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites purified themselves and washed their clothes. Then Aaron presented them as a wave offering before the Lord and made atonement for them to purify them.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that, the Levites came to do their work at the tent of meeting under the supervision of Aaron and his sons. They did with the Levites just as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This applies to the Levites: Men twenty-five years old or more shall come to take part in the work at the tent of meeting,
speaker: Narrator

text: but at the age of fifty, they must retire from their regular service and work no longer.
speaker: Narrator

text: They may assist their brothers in performing their duties at the tent of meeting, but they themselves must not do the work. This, then, is how you are to assign the responsibilities of the Levites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses in the Desert of Sinai in the first month of the second year after they came out of Egypt. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Have the Israelites celebrate the Passover at the appointed time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Celebrate it at the appointed time, at twilight on the fourteenth day of this month, in accordance with all its rules and regulations.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses told the Israelites to celebrate the Passover,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they did so in the Desert of Sinai at twilight on the fourteenth day of the first month. The Israelites did everything just as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: But some of them could not celebrate the Passover on that day because they were ceremonially unclean on account of a dead body. So they came to Moses and Aaron that same day
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to Moses, “We have become unclean because of a dead body, but why should we be kept from presenting the Lord’s offering with the other Israelites at the appointed time?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses answered them, “Wait until I find out what the Lord commands concerning you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: ‘When any of you or your descendants are unclean because of a dead body or are away on a journey, they are still to celebrate the Lord’s Passover,
speaker: Narrator

text: but they are to do it on the fourteenth day of the second month at twilight. They are to eat the lamb, together with unleavened bread and bitter herbs.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must not leave any of it till morning or break any of its bones. When they celebrate the Passover, they must follow all the regulations.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if anyone who is ceremonially clean and not on a journey fails to celebrate the Passover, they must be cut off from their people for not presenting the Lord’s offering at the appointed time. They will bear the consequences of their sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘A foreigner residing among you is also to celebrate the Lord’s Passover in accordance with its rules and regulations. You must have the same regulations for both the foreigner and the native-born.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day the tabernacle, the tent of the covenant law, was set up, the cloud covered it. From evening till morning the cloud above the tabernacle looked like fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is how it continued to be; the cloud covered it, and at night it looked like fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the cloud lifted from above the tent, the Israelites set out; wherever the cloud settled, the Israelites encamped.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the Lord’s command the Israelites set out, and at his command they encamped. As long as the cloud stayed over the tabernacle, they remained in camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the cloud remained over the tabernacle a long time, the Israelites obeyed the Lord’s order and did not set out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sometimes the cloud was over the tabernacle only a few days; at the Lord’s command they would encamp, and then at his command they would set out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sometimes the cloud stayed only from evening till morning, and when it lifted in the morning, they set out. Whether by day or by night, whenever the cloud lifted, they set out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whether the cloud stayed over the tabernacle for two days or a month or a year, the Israelites would remain in camp and not set out; but when it lifted, they would set out.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the Lord’s command they encamped, and at the Lord’s command they set out. They obeyed the Lord’s order, in accordance with his command through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make two trumpets of hammered silver, and use them for calling the community together and for having the camps set out.
speaker: Narrator

text: When both are sounded, the whole community is to assemble before you at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: If only one is sounded, the leaders—the heads of the clans of Israel—are to assemble before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a trumpet blast is sounded, the tribes camping on the east are to set out.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the sounding of a second blast, the camps on the south are to set out. The blast will be the signal for setting out.
speaker: Narrator

text: To gather the assembly, blow the trumpets, but not with the signal for setting out.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The sons of Aaron, the priests, are to blow the trumpets. This is to be a lasting ordinance for you and the generations to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you go into battle in your own land against an enemy who is oppressing you, sound a blast on the trumpets. Then you will be remembered by the Lord your God and rescued from your enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also at your times of rejoicing—your appointed festivals and New Moon feasts—you are to sound the trumpets over your burnt offerings and fellowship offerings, and they will be a memorial for you before your God. I am the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the twentieth day of the second month of the second year, the cloud lifted from above the tabernacle of the covenant law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Israelites set out from the Desert of Sinai and traveled from place to place until the cloud came to rest in the Desert of Paran.
speaker: Narrator

text: They set out, this first time, at the Lord’s command through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The divisions of the camp of Judah went first, under their standard. Nahshon son of Amminadab was in command.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nethanel son of Zuar was over the division of the tribe of Issachar,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Eliab son of Helon was over the division of the tribe of Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the tabernacle was taken down, and the Gershonites and Merarites, who carried it, set out.
speaker: Narrator

text: The divisions of the camp of Reuben went next, under their standard. Elizur son of Shedeur was in command.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shelumiel son of Zurishaddai was over the division of the tribe of Simeon,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Eliasaph son of Deuel was over the division of the tribe of Gad.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Kohathites set out, carrying the holy things. The tabernacle was to be set up before they arrived.
speaker: Narrator

text: The divisions of the camp of Ephraim went next, under their standard. Elishama son of Ammihud was in command.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gamaliel son of Pedahzur was over the division of the tribe of Manasseh,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Abidan son of Gideoni was over the division of the tribe of Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, as the rear guard for all the units, the divisions of the camp of Dan set out under their standard. Ahiezer son of Ammishaddai was in command.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pagiel son of Okran was over the division of the tribe of Asher,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Ahira son of Enan was over the division of the tribe of Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the order of march for the Israelite divisions as they set out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Moses said to Hobab son of Reuel the Midianite, Moses’ father-in-law, “We are setting out for the place about which the Lord said, ‘I will give it to you.’ Come with us and we will treat you well, for the Lord has promised good things to Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He answered, “No, I will not go; I am going back to my own land and my own people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said, “Please do not leave us. You know where we should camp in the wilderness, and you can be our eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you come with us, we will share with you whatever good things the Lord gives us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they set out from the mountain of the Lord and traveled for three days. The ark of the covenant of the Lord went before them during those three days to find them a place to rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cloud of the Lord was over them by day when they set out from the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whenever the ark set out, Moses said,
“Rise up, Lord!
    May your enemies be scattered;
    may your foes flee before you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whenever it came to rest, he said,
“Return, Lord,
    to the countless thousands of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the people complained about their hardships in the hearing of the Lord, and when he heard them his anger was aroused. Then fire from the Lord burned among them and consumed some of the outskirts of the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people cried out to Moses, he prayed to the Lord and the fire died down.
speaker: Narrator

text: So that place was called Taberah, because fire from the Lord had burned among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rabble with them began to crave other food, and again the Israelites started wailing and said, “If only we had meat to eat!
speaker: Narrator

text: We remember the fish we ate in Egypt at no cost—also the cucumbers, melons, leeks, onions and garlic.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now we have lost our appetite; we never see anything but this manna!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The manna was like coriander seed and looked like resin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people went around gathering it, and then ground it in a hand mill or crushed it in a mortar. They cooked it in a pot or made it into loaves. And it tasted like something made with olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the dew settled on the camp at night, the manna also came down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses heard the people of every family wailing at the entrance to their tents. The Lord became exceedingly angry, and Moses was troubled.
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked the Lord, “Why have you brought this trouble on your servant? What have I done to displease you that you put the burden of all these people on me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Did I conceive all these people? Did I give them birth? Why do you tell me to carry them in my arms, as a nurse carries an infant, to the land you promised on oath to their ancestors?
speaker: Narrator

text: Where can I get meat for all these people? They keep wailing to me, ‘Give us meat to eat!’
speaker: Narrator

text: I cannot carry all these people by myself; the burden is too heavy for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If this is how you are going to treat me, please go ahead and kill me—if I have found favor in your eyes—and do not let me face my own ruin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses: “Bring me seventy of Israel’s elders who are known to you as leaders and officials among the people. Have them come to the tent of meeting, that they may stand there with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will come down and speak with you there, and I will take some of the power of the Spirit that is on you and put it on them. They will share the burden of the people with you so that you will not have to carry it alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the people: ‘Consecrate yourselves in preparation for tomorrow, when you will eat meat. The Lord heard you when you wailed, “If only we had meat to eat! We were better off in Egypt!” Now the Lord will give you meat, and you will eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will not eat it for just one day, or two days, or five, ten or twenty days,
speaker: Narrator

text: but for a whole month—until it comes out of your nostrils and you loathe it—because you have rejected the Lord, who is among you, and have wailed before him, saying, “Why did we ever leave Egypt?”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said, “Here I am among six hundred thousand men on foot, and you say, ‘I will give them meat to eat for a whole month!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Would they have enough if flocks and herds were slaughtered for them? Would they have enough if all the fish in the sea were caught for them?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord answered Moses, “Is the Lord’s arm too short? Now you will see whether or not what I say will come true for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses went out and told the people what the Lord had said. He brought together seventy of their elders and had them stand around the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord came down in the cloud and spoke with him, and he took some of the power of the Spirit that was on him and put it on the seventy elders. When the Spirit rested on them, they prophesied—but did not do so again.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, two men, whose names were Eldad and Medad, had remained in the camp. They were listed among the elders, but did not go out to the tent. Yet the Spirit also rested on them, and they prophesied in the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: A young man ran and told Moses, “Eldad and Medad are prophesying in the camp.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua son of Nun, who had been Moses’ aide since youth, spoke up and said, “Moses, my lord, stop them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses replied, “Are you jealous for my sake? I wish that all the Lord’s people were prophets and that the Lord would put his Spirit on them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and the elders of Israel returned to the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now a wind went out from the Lord and drove quail in from the sea. It scattered them up to two cubits deep all around the camp, as far as a day’s walk in any direction.
speaker: Narrator

text: All that day and night and all the next day the people went out and gathered quail. No one gathered less than ten homers. Then they spread them out all around the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: But while the meat was still between their teeth and before it could be consumed, the anger of the Lord burned against the people, and he struck them with a severe plague.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the place was named Kibroth Hattaavah, because there they buried the people who had craved other food.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Kibroth Hattaavah the people traveled to Hazeroth and stayed there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Miriam and Aaron began to talk against Moses because of his Cushite wife, for he had married a Cushite.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Has the Lord spoken only through Moses?” they asked. “Hasn’t he also spoken through us?” And the Lord heard this.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Now Moses was a very humble man, more humble than anyone else on the face of the earth.)
speaker: Narrator

text: At once the Lord said to Moses, Aaron and Miriam, “Come out to the tent of meeting, all three of you.” So the three of them went out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord came down in a pillar of cloud; he stood at the entrance to the tent and summoned Aaron and Miriam. When the two of them stepped forward,
speaker: Narrator

text:
he said, “Listen to my words:
“When there is a prophet among you,
    I, the Lord, reveal myself to them in visions,
    I speak to them in dreams.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But this is not true of my servant Moses;
    he is faithful in all my house.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With him I speak face to face,
    clearly and not in riddles;
    he sees the form of the Lord.
Why then were you not afraid
    to speak against my servant Moses?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The anger of the Lord burned against them, and he left them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the cloud lifted from above the tent, Miriam’s skin was leprous—it became as white as snow. Aaron turned toward her and saw that she had a defiling skin disease,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he said to Moses, “Please, my lord, I ask you not to hold against us the sin we have so foolishly committed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not let her be like a stillborn infant coming from its mother’s womb with its flesh half eaten away.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses cried out to the Lord, “Please, God, heal her!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord replied to Moses, “If her father had spit in her face, would she not have been in disgrace for seven days? Confine her outside the camp for seven days; after that she can be brought back.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Miriam was confined outside the camp for seven days, and the people did not move on till she was brought back.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that, the people left Hazeroth and encamped in the Desert of Paran.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Send some men to explore the land of Canaan, which I am giving to the Israelites. From each ancestral tribe send one of its leaders.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So at the Lord’s command Moses sent them out from the Desert of Paran. All of them were leaders of the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are their names:
from the tribe of Reuben, Shammua son of Zakkur;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Simeon, Shaphat son of Hori;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Judah, Caleb son of Jephunneh;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Issachar, Igal son of Joseph;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Ephraim, Hoshea son of Nun;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Benjamin, Palti son of Raphu;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Zebulun, Gaddiel son of Sodi;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Manasseh (a tribe of Joseph), Gaddi son of Susi;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Dan, Ammiel son of Gemalli;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Asher, Sethur son of Michael;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Naphtali, Nahbi son of Vophsi;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Gad, Geuel son of Maki.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of the men Moses sent to explore the land. (Moses gave Hoshea son of Nun the name Joshua.)
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses sent them to explore Canaan, he said, “Go up through the Negev and on into the hill country.
speaker: Narrator

text: See what the land is like and whether the people who live there are strong or weak, few or many.
speaker: Narrator

text: What kind of land do they live in? Is it good or bad? What kind of towns do they live in? Are they unwalled or fortified?
speaker: Narrator

text: How is the soil? Is it fertile or poor? Are there trees in it or not? Do your best to bring back some of the fruit of the land.” (It was the season for the first ripe grapes.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went up and explored the land from the Desert of Zin as far as Rehob, toward Lebo Hamath.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went up through the Negev and came to Hebron, where Ahiman, Sheshai and Talmai, the descendants of Anak, lived. (Hebron had been built seven years before Zoan in Egypt.)
speaker: Narrator

text: When they reached the Valley of Eshkol, they cut off a branch bearing a single cluster of grapes. Two of them carried it on a pole between them, along with some pomegranates and figs.
speaker: Narrator

text: That place was called the Valley of Eshkol because of the cluster of grapes the Israelites cut off there.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of forty days they returned from exploring the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came back to Moses and Aaron and the whole Israelite community at Kadesh in the Desert of Paran. There they reported to them and to the whole assembly and showed them the fruit of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: They gave Moses this account: “We went into the land to which you sent us, and it does flow with milk and honey! Here is its fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people who live there are powerful, and the cities are fortified and very large. We even saw descendants of Anak there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Amalekites live in the Negev; the Hittites, Jebusites and Amorites live in the hill country; and the Canaanites live near the sea and along the Jordan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Caleb silenced the people before Moses and said, “We should go up and take possession of the land, for we can certainly do it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the men who had gone up with him said, “We can’t attack those people; they are stronger than we are.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they spread among the Israelites a bad report about the land they had explored. They said, “The land we explored devours those living in it. All the people we saw there are of great size.
speaker: Narrator

text: We saw the Nephilim there (the descendants of Anak come from the Nephilim). We seemed like grasshoppers in our own eyes, and we looked the same to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That night all the members of the community raised their voices and wept aloud.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Israelites grumbled against Moses and Aaron, and the whole assembly said to them, “If only we had died in Egypt! Or in this wilderness!
speaker: Narrator

text: Why is the Lord bringing us to this land only to let us fall by the sword? Our wives and children will be taken as plunder. Wouldn’t it be better for us to go back to Egypt?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said to each other, “We should choose a leader and go back to Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron fell facedown in front of the whole Israelite assembly gathered there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua son of Nun and Caleb son of Jephunneh, who were among those who had explored the land, tore their clothes
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to the entire Israelite assembly, “The land we passed through and explored is exceedingly good.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the Lord is pleased with us, he will lead us into that land, a land flowing with milk and honey, and will give it to us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only do not rebel against the Lord. And do not be afraid of the people of the land, because we will devour them. Their protection is gone, but the Lord is with us. Do not be afraid of them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the whole assembly talked about stoning them. Then the glory of the Lord appeared at the tent of meeting to all the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “How long will these people treat me with contempt? How long will they refuse to believe in me, in spite of all the signs I have performed among them?
speaker: Narrator

text: I will strike them down with a plague and destroy them, but I will make you into a nation greater and stronger than they.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the Lord, “Then the Egyptians will hear about it! By your power you brought these people up from among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they will tell the inhabitants of this land about it. They have already heard that you, Lord, are with these people and that you, Lord, have been seen face to face, that your cloud stays over them, and that you go before them in a pillar of cloud by day and a pillar of fire by night.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you put all these people to death, leaving none alive, the nations who have heard this report about you will say,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The Lord was not able to bring these people into the land he promised them on oath, so he slaughtered them in the wilderness.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now may the Lord’s strength be displayed, just as you have declared:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The Lord is slow to anger, abounding in love and forgiving sin and rebellion. Yet he does not leave the guilty unpunished; he punishes the children for the sin of the parents to the third and fourth generation.’
speaker: Narrator

text: In accordance with your great love, forgive the sin of these people, just as you have pardoned them from the time they left Egypt until now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord replied, “I have forgiven them, as you asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, as surely as I live and as surely as the glory of the Lord fills the whole earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: not one of those who saw my glory and the signs I performed in Egypt and in the wilderness but who disobeyed me and tested me ten times—
speaker: Narrator

text: not one of them will ever see the land I promised on oath to their ancestors. No one who has treated me with contempt will ever see it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But because my servant Caleb has a different spirit and follows me wholeheartedly, I will bring him into the land he went to, and his descendants will inherit it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since the Amalekites and the Canaanites are living in the valleys, turn back tomorrow and set out toward the desert along the route to the Red Sea.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron:
speaker: Narrator

text: “How long will this wicked community grumble against me? I have heard the complaints of these grumbling Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: So tell them, ‘As surely as I live, declares the Lord, I will do to you the very thing I heard you say:
speaker: Narrator

text: In this wilderness your bodies will fall—every one of you twenty years old or more who was counted in the census and who has grumbled against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not one of you will enter the land I swore with uplifted hand to make your home, except Caleb son of Jephunneh and Joshua son of Nun.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for your children that you said would be taken as plunder, I will bring them in to enjoy the land you have rejected.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for you, your bodies will fall in this wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your children will be shepherds here for forty years, suffering for your unfaithfulness, until the last of your bodies lies in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: For forty years—one year for each of the forty days you explored the land—you will suffer for your sins and know what it is like to have me against you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I, the Lord, have spoken, and I will surely do these things to this whole wicked community, which has banded together against me. They will meet their end in this wilderness; here they will die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the men Moses had sent to explore the land, who returned and made the whole community grumble against him by spreading a bad report about it—
speaker: Narrator

text: these men who were responsible for spreading the bad report about the land were struck down and died of a plague before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of the men who went to explore the land, only Joshua son of Nun and Caleb son of Jephunneh survived.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses reported this to all the Israelites, they mourned bitterly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Early the next morning they set out for the highest point in the hill country, saying, “Now we are ready to go up to the land the Lord promised. Surely we have sinned!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said, “Why are you disobeying the Lord’s command? This will not succeed!
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not go up, because the Lord is not with you. You will be defeated by your enemies,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the Amalekites and the Canaanites will face you there. Because you have turned away from the Lord, he will not be with you and you will fall by the sword.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, in their presumption they went up toward the highest point in the hill country, though neither Moses nor the ark of the Lord’s covenant moved from the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Amalekites and the Canaanites who lived in that hill country came down and attacked them and beat them down all the way to Hormah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and say to them: ‘After you enter the land I am giving you as a home
speaker: Narrator

text: and you present to the Lord food offerings from the herd or the flock, as an aroma pleasing to the Lord—whether burnt offerings or sacrifices, for special vows or freewill offerings or festival offerings—
speaker: Narrator

text: then the person who brings an offering shall present to the Lord a grain offering of a tenth of an ephah of the finest flour mixed with a quarter of a hin of olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: With each lamb for the burnt offering or the sacrifice, prepare a quarter of a hin of wine as a drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘With a ram prepare a grain offering of two-tenths of an ephah of the finest flour mixed with a third of a hin of olive oil,
speaker: Narrator

text: and a third of a hin of wine as a drink offering. Offer it as an aroma pleasing to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘When you prepare a young bull as a burnt offering or sacrifice, for a special vow or a fellowship offering to the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: bring with the bull a grain offering of three-tenths of an ephah of the finest flour mixed with half a hin of olive oil,
speaker: Narrator

text: and also bring half a hin of wine as a drink offering. This will be a food offering, an aroma pleasing to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each bull or ram, each lamb or young goat, is to be prepared in this manner.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do this for each one, for as many as you prepare.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Everyone who is native-born must do these things in this way when they present a food offering as an aroma pleasing to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the generations to come, whenever a foreigner or anyone else living among you presents a food offering as an aroma pleasing to the Lord, they must do exactly as you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: The community is to have the same rules for you and for the foreigner residing among you; this is a lasting ordinance for the generations to come. You and the foreigner shall be the same before the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text: The same laws and regulations will apply both to you and to the foreigner residing among you.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and say to them: ‘When you enter the land to which I am taking you
speaker: Narrator

text: and you eat the food of the land, present a portion as an offering to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Present a loaf from the first of your ground meal and present it as an offering from the threshing floor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Throughout the generations to come you are to give this offering to the Lord from the first of your ground meal.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Now if you as a community unintentionally fail to keep any of these commands the Lord gave Moses—
speaker: Narrator

text: any of the Lord’s commands to you through him, from the day the Lord gave them and continuing through the generations to come—
speaker: Narrator

text: and if this is done unintentionally without the community being aware of it, then the whole community is to offer a young bull for a burnt offering as an aroma pleasing to the Lord, along with its prescribed grain offering and drink offering, and a male goat for a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to make atonement for the whole Israelite community, and they will be forgiven, for it was not intentional and they have presented to the Lord for their wrong a food offering and a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole Israelite community and the foreigners residing among them will be forgiven, because all the people were involved in the unintentional wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘But if just one person sins unintentionally, that person must bring a year-old female goat for a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to make atonement before the Lord for the one who erred by sinning unintentionally, and when atonement has been made, that person will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: One and the same law applies to everyone who sins unintentionally, whether a native-born Israelite or a foreigner residing among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘But anyone who sins defiantly, whether native-born or foreigner, blasphemes the Lord and must be cut off from the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because they have despised the Lord’s word and broken his commands, they must surely be cut off; their guilt remains on them.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: While the Israelites were in the wilderness, a man was found gathering wood on the Sabbath day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who found him gathering wood brought him to Moses and Aaron and the whole assembly,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they kept him in custody, because it was not clear what should be done to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “The man must die. The whole assembly must stone him outside the camp.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the assembly took him outside the camp and stoned him to death, as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and say to them: ‘Throughout the generations to come you are to make tassels on the corners of your garments, with a blue cord on each tassel.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will have these tassels to look at and so you will remember all the commands of the Lord, that you may obey them and not prostitute yourselves by chasing after the lusts of your own hearts and eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will remember to obey all my commands and will be consecrated to your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of Egypt to be your God. I am the Lord your God.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Korah son of Izhar, the son of Kohath, the son of Levi, and certain Reubenites—Dathan and Abiram, sons of Eliab, and On son of Peleth—became insolent
speaker: Narrator

text: and rose up against Moses. With them were 250 Israelite men, well-known community leaders who had been appointed members of the council.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came as a group to oppose Moses and Aaron and said to them, “You have gone too far! The whole community is holy, every one of them, and the Lord is with them. Why then do you set yourselves above the Lord’s assembly?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses heard this, he fell facedown.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to Korah and all his followers: “In the morning the Lord will show who belongs to him and who is holy, and he will have that person come near him. The man he chooses he will cause to come near him.
speaker: Narrator

text: You, Korah, and all your followers are to do this: Take censers
speaker: Narrator

text: and tomorrow put burning coals and incense in them before the Lord. The man the Lord chooses will be the one who is holy. You Levites have gone too far!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses also said to Korah, “Now listen, you Levites!
speaker: Narrator

text: Isn’t it enough for you that the God of Israel has separated you from the rest of the Israelite community and brought you near himself to do the work at the Lord’s tabernacle and to stand before the community and minister to them?
speaker: Narrator

text: He has brought you and all your fellow Levites near himself, but now you are trying to get the priesthood too.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is against the Lord that you and all your followers have banded together. Who is Aaron that you should grumble against him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses summoned Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab. But they said, “We will not come!
speaker: Narrator

text: Isn’t it enough that you have brought us up out of a land flowing with milk and honey to kill us in the wilderness? And now you also want to lord it over us!
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, you haven’t brought us into a land flowing with milk and honey or given us an inheritance of fields and vineyards. Do you want to treat these men like slaves? No, we will not come!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses became very angry and said to the Lord, “Do not accept their offering. I have not taken so much as a donkey from them, nor have I wronged any of them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Korah, “You and all your followers are to appear before the Lord tomorrow—you and they and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each man is to take his censer and put incense in it—250 censers in all—and present it before the Lord. You and Aaron are to present your censers also.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So each of them took his censer, put burning coals and incense in it, and stood with Moses and Aaron at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Korah had gathered all his followers in opposition to them at the entrance to the tent of meeting, the glory of the Lord appeared to the entire assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Separate yourselves from this assembly so I can put an end to them at once.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses and Aaron fell facedown and cried out, “O God, the God who gives breath to all living things, will you be angry with the entire assembly when only one man sins?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to the assembly, ‘Move away from the tents of Korah, Dathan and Abiram.’”
speaker: Narrator
