text: Moses got up and went to Dathan and Abiram, and the elders of Israel followed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He warned the assembly, “Move back from the tents of these wicked men! Do not touch anything belonging to them, or you will be swept away because of all their sins.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they moved away from the tents of Korah, Dathan and Abiram. Dathan and Abiram had come out and were standing with their wives, children and little ones at the entrances to their tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said, “This is how you will know that the Lord has sent me to do all these things and that it was not my idea:
speaker: Narrator

text: If these men die a natural death and suffer the fate of all mankind, then the Lord has not sent me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the Lord brings about something totally new, and the earth opens its mouth and swallows them, with everything that belongs to them, and they go down alive into the realm of the dead, then you will know that these men have treated the Lord with contempt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he finished saying all this, the ground under them split apart
speaker: Narrator

text: and the earth opened its mouth and swallowed them and their households, and all those associated with Korah, together with their possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went down alive into the realm of the dead, with everything they owned; the earth closed over them, and they perished and were gone from the community.
speaker: Narrator

text: At their cries, all the Israelites around them fled, shouting, “The earth is going to swallow us too!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And fire came out from the Lord and consumed the 250 men who were offering the incense.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell Eleazar son of Aaron, the priest, to remove the censers from the charred remains and scatter the coals some distance away, for the censers are holy—
speaker: Narrator

text: the censers of the men who sinned at the cost of their lives. Hammer the censers into sheets to overlay the altar, for they were presented before the Lord and have become holy. Let them be a sign to the Israelites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Eleazar the priest collected the bronze censers brought by those who had been burned to death, and he had them hammered out to overlay the altar,
speaker: Narrator

text: as the Lord directed him through Moses. This was to remind the Israelites that no one except a descendant of Aaron should come to burn incense before the Lord, or he would become like Korah and his followers.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day the whole Israelite community grumbled against Moses and Aaron. “You have killed the Lord’s people,” they said.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the assembly gathered in opposition to Moses and Aaron and turned toward the tent of meeting, suddenly the cloud covered it and the glory of the Lord appeared.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron went to the front of the tent of meeting,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Get away from this assembly so I can put an end to them at once.” And they fell facedown.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to Aaron, “Take your censer and put incense in it, along with burning coals from the altar, and hurry to the assembly to make atonement for them. Wrath has come out from the Lord; the plague has started.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Aaron did as Moses said, and ran into the midst of the assembly. The plague had already started among the people, but Aaron offered the incense and made atonement for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stood between the living and the dead, and the plague stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: But 14,700 people died from the plague, in addition to those who had died because of Korah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Aaron returned to Moses at the entrance to the tent of meeting, for the plague had stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and get twelve staffs from them, one from the leader of each of their ancestral tribes. Write the name of each man on his staff.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the staff of Levi write Aaron’s name, for there must be one staff for the head of each ancestral tribe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Place them in the tent of meeting in front of the ark of the covenant law, where I meet with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The staff belonging to the man I choose will sprout, and I will rid myself of this constant grumbling against you by the Israelites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses spoke to the Israelites, and their leaders gave him twelve staffs, one for the leader of each of their ancestral tribes, and Aaron’s staff was among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses placed the staffs before the Lord in the tent of the covenant law.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day Moses entered the tent and saw that Aaron’s staff, which represented the tribe of Levi, had not only sprouted but had budded, blossomed and produced almonds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses brought out all the staffs from the Lord’s presence to all the Israelites. They looked at them, and each of the leaders took his own staff.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Put back Aaron’s staff in front of the ark of the covenant law, to be kept as a sign to the rebellious. This will put an end to their grumbling against me, so that they will not die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses did just as the Lord commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites said to Moses, “We will die! We are lost, we are all lost!
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who even comes near the tabernacle of the Lord will die. Are we all going to die?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Aaron, “You, your sons and your family are to bear the responsibility for offenses connected with the sanctuary, and you and your sons alone are to bear the responsibility for offenses connected with the priesthood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring your fellow Levites from your ancestral tribe to join you and assist you when you and your sons minister before the tent of the covenant law.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are to be responsible to you and are to perform all the duties of the tent, but they must not go near the furnishings of the sanctuary or the altar. Otherwise both they and you will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are to join you and be responsible for the care of the tent of meeting—all the work at the tent—and no one else may come near where you are.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to be responsible for the care of the sanctuary and the altar, so that my wrath will not fall on the Israelites again.
speaker: Narrator

text: I myself have selected your fellow Levites from among the Israelites as a gift to you, dedicated to the Lord to do the work at the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: But only you and your sons may serve as priests in connection with everything at the altar and inside the curtain. I am giving you the service of the priesthood as a gift. Anyone else who comes near the sanctuary is to be put to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Aaron, “I myself have put you in charge of the offerings presented to me; all the holy offerings the Israelites give me I give to you and your sons as your portion, your perpetual share.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to have the part of the most holy offerings that is kept from the fire. From all the gifts they bring me as most holy offerings, whether grain or sin or guilt offerings, that part belongs to you and your sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eat it as something most holy; every male shall eat it. You must regard it as holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This also is yours: whatever is set aside from the gifts of all the wave offerings of the Israelites. I give this to you and your sons and daughters as your perpetual share. Everyone in your household who is ceremonially clean may eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I give you all the finest olive oil and all the finest new wine and grain they give the Lord as the firstfruits of their harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the land’s firstfruits that they bring to the Lord will be yours. Everyone in your household who is ceremonially clean may eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Everything in Israel that is devoted to the Lord is yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first offspring of every womb, both human and animal, that is offered to the Lord is yours. But you must redeem every firstborn son and every firstborn male of unclean animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they are a month old, you must redeem them at the redemption price set at five shekels of silver, according to the sanctuary shekel, which weighs twenty gerahs.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But you must not redeem the firstborn of a cow, a sheep or a goat; they are holy. Splash their blood against the altar and burn their fat as a food offering, an aroma pleasing to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their meat is to be yours, just as the breast of the wave offering and the right thigh are yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever is set aside from the holy offerings the Israelites present to the Lord I give to you and your sons and daughters as your perpetual share. It is an everlasting covenant of salt before the Lord for both you and your offspring.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Aaron, “You will have no inheritance in their land, nor will you have any share among them; I am your share and your inheritance among the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I give to the Levites all the tithes in Israel as their inheritance in return for the work they do while serving at the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: From now on the Israelites must not go near the tent of meeting, or they will bear the consequences of their sin and will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is the Levites who are to do the work at the tent of meeting and bear the responsibility for any offenses they commit against it. This is a lasting ordinance for the generations to come. They will receive no inheritance among the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, I give to the Levites as their inheritance the tithes that the Israelites present as an offering to the Lord. That is why I said concerning them: ‘They will have no inheritance among the Israelites.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Levites and say to them: ‘When you receive from the Israelites the tithe I give you as your inheritance, you must present a tenth of that tithe as the Lord’s offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your offering will be reckoned to you as grain from the threshing floor or juice from the winepress.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way you also will present an offering to the Lord from all the tithes you receive from the Israelites. From these tithes you must give the Lord’s portion to Aaron the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must present as the Lord’s portion the best and holiest part of everything given to you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to the Levites: ‘When you present the best part, it will be reckoned to you as the product of the threshing floor or the winepress.
speaker: Narrator

text: You and your households may eat the rest of it anywhere, for it is your wages for your work at the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: By presenting the best part of it you will not be guilty in this matter; then you will not defile the holy offerings of the Israelites, and you will not die.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron:
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is a requirement of the law that the Lord has commanded: Tell the Israelites to bring you a red heifer without defect or blemish and that has never been under a yoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give it to Eleazar the priest; it is to be taken outside the camp and slaughtered in his presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eleazar the priest is to take some of its blood on his finger and sprinkle it seven times toward the front of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: While he watches, the heifer is to be burned—its hide, flesh, blood and intestines.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to take some cedar wood, hyssop and scarlet wool and throw them onto the burning heifer.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that, the priest must wash his clothes and bathe himself with water. He may then come into the camp, but he will be ceremonially unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man who burns it must also wash his clothes and bathe with water, and he too will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A man who is clean shall gather up the ashes of the heifer and put them in a ceremonially clean place outside the camp. They are to be kept by the Israelite community for use in the water of cleansing; it is for purification from sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man who gathers up the ashes of the heifer must also wash his clothes, and he too will be unclean till evening. This will be a lasting ordinance both for the Israelites and for the foreigners residing among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever touches a human corpse will be unclean for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must purify themselves with the water on the third day and on the seventh day; then they will be clean. But if they do not purify themselves on the third and seventh days, they will not be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they fail to purify themselves after touching a human corpse, they defile the Lord’s tabernacle. They must be cut off from Israel. Because the water of cleansing has not been sprinkled on them, they are unclean; their uncleanness remains on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the law that applies when a person dies in a tent: Anyone who enters the tent and anyone who is in it will be unclean for seven days,
speaker: Narrator

text: and every open container without a lid fastened on it will be unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Anyone out in the open who touches someone who has been killed with a sword or someone who has died a natural death, or anyone who touches a human bone or a grave, will be unclean for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For the unclean person, put some ashes from the burned purification offering into a jar and pour fresh water over them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a man who is ceremonially clean is to take some hyssop, dip it in the water and sprinkle the tent and all the furnishings and the people who were there. He must also sprinkle anyone who has touched a human bone or a grave or anyone who has been killed or anyone who has died a natural death.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man who is clean is to sprinkle those who are unclean on the third and seventh days, and on the seventh day he is to purify them. Those who are being cleansed must wash their clothes and bathe with water, and that evening they will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if those who are unclean do not purify themselves, they must be cut off from the community, because they have defiled the sanctuary of the Lord. The water of cleansing has not been sprinkled on them, and they are unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is a lasting ordinance for them.
“The man who sprinkles the water of cleansing must also wash his clothes, and anyone who touches the water of cleansing will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anything that an unclean person touches becomes unclean, and anyone who touches it becomes unclean till evening.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the first month the whole Israelite community arrived at the Desert of Zin, and they stayed at Kadesh. There Miriam died and was buried.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was no water for the community, and the people gathered in opposition to Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: They quarreled with Moses and said, “If only we had died when our brothers fell dead before the Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text: Why did you bring the Lord’s community into this wilderness, that we and our livestock should die here?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why did you bring us up out of Egypt to this terrible place? It has no grain or figs, grapevines or pomegranates. And there is no water to drink!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron went from the assembly to the entrance to the tent of meeting and fell facedown, and the glory of the Lord appeared to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take the staff, and you and your brother Aaron gather the assembly together. Speak to that rock before their eyes and it will pour out its water. You will bring water out of the rock for the community so they and their livestock can drink.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses took the staff from the Lord’s presence, just as he commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He and Aaron gathered the assembly together in front of the rock and Moses said to them, “Listen, you rebels, must we bring you water out of this rock?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses raised his arm and struck the rock twice with his staff. Water gushed out, and the community and their livestock drank.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “Because you did not trust in me enough to honor me as holy in the sight of the Israelites, you will not bring this community into the land I give them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the waters of Meribah, where the Israelites quarreled with the Lord and where he was proved holy among them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses sent messengers from Kadesh to the king of Edom, saying:
“This is what your brother Israel says: You know about all the hardships that have come on us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our ancestors went down into Egypt, and we lived there many years. The Egyptians mistreated us and our ancestors,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but when we cried out to the Lord, he heard our cry and sent an angel and brought us out of Egypt.
“Now we are here at Kadesh, a town on the edge of your territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please let us pass through your country. We will not go through any field or vineyard, or drink water from any well. We will travel along the King’s Highway and not turn to the right or to the left until we have passed through your territory.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But Edom answered:
“You may not pass through here; if you try, we will march out and attack you with the sword.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Israelites replied:
“We will go along the main road, and if we or our livestock drink any of your water, we will pay for it. We only want to pass through on foot—nothing else.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Again they answered:
“You may not pass through.”
Then Edom came out against them with a large and powerful army.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since Edom refused to let them go through their territory, Israel turned away from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole Israelite community set out from Kadesh and came to Mount Hor.
speaker: Narrator

text: At Mount Hor, near the border of Edom, the Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Aaron will be gathered to his people. He will not enter the land I give the Israelites, because both of you rebelled against my command at the waters of Meribah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get Aaron and his son Eleazar and take them up Mount Hor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remove Aaron’s garments and put them on his son Eleazar, for Aaron will be gathered to his people; he will die there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses did as the Lord commanded: They went up Mount Hor in the sight of the whole community.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses removed Aaron’s garments and put them on his son Eleazar. And Aaron died there on top of the mountain. Then Moses and Eleazar came down from the mountain,
speaker: Narrator

text: and when the whole community learned that Aaron had died, all the Israelites mourned for him thirty days.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Canaanite king of Arad, who lived in the Negev, heard that Israel was coming along the road to Atharim, he attacked the Israelites and captured some of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Israel made this vow to the Lord: “If you will deliver these people into our hands, we will totally destroy their cities.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord listened to Israel’s plea and gave the Canaanites over to them. They completely destroyed them and their towns; so the place was named Hormah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They traveled from Mount Hor along the route to the Red Sea, to go around Edom. But the people grew impatient on the way;
speaker: Narrator

text: they spoke against God and against Moses, and said, “Why have you brought us up out of Egypt to die in the wilderness? There is no bread! There is no water! And we detest this miserable food!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord sent venomous snakes among them; they bit the people and many Israelites died.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people came to Moses and said, “We sinned when we spoke against the Lord and against you. Pray that the Lord will take the snakes away from us.” So Moses prayed for the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Make a snake and put it up on a pole; anyone who is bitten can look at it and live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses made a bronze snake and put it up on a pole. Then when anyone was bitten by a snake and looked at the bronze snake, they lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites moved on and camped at Oboth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they set out from Oboth and camped in Iye Abarim, in the wilderness that faces Moab toward the sunrise.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they moved on and camped in the Zered Valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: They set out from there and camped alongside the Arnon, which is in the wilderness extending into Amorite territory. The Arnon is the border of Moab, between Moab and the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why the Book of the Wars of the Lord says:
“. . . Zahab in Suphah and the ravines,
    the Arnon
speaker: Narrator

text:
and the slopes of the ravines
that lead to the settlement of Ar
    and lie along the border of Moab.”
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they continued on to Beer, the well where the Lord said to Moses, “Gather the people together and I will give them water.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Israel sang this song:
“Spring up, O well!
    Sing about it,
speaker: Narrator

text:
about the well that the princes dug,
    that the nobles of the people sank—
    the nobles with scepters and staffs.”
Then they went from the wilderness to Mattanah,
speaker: Narrator

text: from Mattanah to Nahaliel, from Nahaliel to Bamoth,
speaker: Narrator

text: and from Bamoth to the valley in Moab where the top of Pisgah overlooks the wasteland.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel sent messengers to say to Sihon king of the Amorites:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let us pass through your country. We will not turn aside into any field or vineyard, or drink water from any well. We will travel along the King’s Highway until we have passed through your territory.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Sihon would not let Israel pass through his territory. He mustered his entire army and marched out into the wilderness against Israel. When he reached Jahaz, he fought with Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel, however, put him to the sword and took over his land from the Arnon to the Jabbok, but only as far as the Ammonites, because their border was fortified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel captured all the cities of the Amorites and occupied them, including Heshbon and all its surrounding settlements.
speaker: Narrator

text: Heshbon was the city of Sihon king of the Amorites, who had fought against the former king of Moab and had taken from him all his land as far as the Arnon.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Fire went out from Heshbon,
    a blaze from the city of Sihon.
It consumed Ar of Moab,
    the citizens of Arnon’s heights.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to you, Moab!
    You are destroyed, people of Chemosh!
He has given up his sons as fugitives
    and his daughters as captives
    to Sihon king of the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But we have overthrown them;
    Heshbon’s dominion has been destroyed all the way to Dibon.
We have demolished them as far as Nophah,
    which extends to Medeba.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel settled in the land of the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Moses had sent spies to Jazer, the Israelites captured its surrounding settlements and drove out the Amorites who were there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they turned and went up along the road toward Bashan, and Og king of Bashan and his whole army marched out to meet them in battle at Edrei.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Do not be afraid of him, for I have delivered him into your hands, along with his whole army and his land. Do to him what you did to Sihon king of the Amorites, who reigned in Heshbon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they struck him down, together with his sons and his whole army, leaving them no survivors. And they took possession of his land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Israelites traveled to the plains of Moab and camped along the Jordan across from Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Balak son of Zippor saw all that Israel had done to the Amorites,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Moab was terrified because there were so many people. Indeed, Moab was filled with dread because of the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Moabites said to the elders of Midian, “This horde is going to lick up everything around us, as an ox licks up the grass of the field.”
So Balak son of Zippor, who was king of Moab at that time,
speaker: Narrator

text:
sent messengers to summon Balaam son of Beor, who was at Pethor, near the Euphrates River, in his native land. Balak said:
“A people has come out of Egypt; they cover the face of the land and have settled next to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now come and put a curse on these people, because they are too powerful for me. Perhaps then I will be able to defeat them and drive them out of the land. For I know that whoever you bless is blessed, and whoever you curse is cursed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of Moab and Midian left, taking with them the fee for divination. When they came to Balaam, they told him what Balak had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Spend the night here,” Balaam said to them, “and I will report back to you with the answer the Lord gives me.” So the Moabite officials stayed with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: God came to Balaam and asked, “Who are these men with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to God, “Balak son of Zippor, king of Moab, sent me this message:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘A people that has come out of Egypt covers the face of the land. Now come and put a curse on them for me. Perhaps then I will be able to fight them and drive them away.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But God said to Balaam, “Do not go with them. You must not put a curse on those people, because they are blessed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The next morning Balaam got up and said to Balak’s officials, “Go back to your own country, for the Lord has refused to let me go with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Moabite officials returned to Balak and said, “Balaam refused to come with us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balak sent other officials, more numerous and more distinguished than the first.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They came to Balaam and said:
“This is what Balak son of Zippor says: Do not let anything keep you from coming to me,
speaker: Narrator

text: because I will reward you handsomely and do whatever you say. Come and put a curse on these people for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Balaam answered them, “Even if Balak gave me all the silver and gold in his palace, I could not do anything great or small to go beyond the command of the Lord my God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now spend the night here so that I can find out what else the Lord will tell me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That night God came to Balaam and said, “Since these men have come to summon you, go with them, but do only what I tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam got up in the morning, saddled his donkey and went with the Moabite officials.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God was very angry when he went, and the angel of the Lord stood in the road to oppose him. Balaam was riding on his donkey, and his two servants were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the donkey saw the angel of the Lord standing in the road with a drawn sword in his hand, it turned off the road into a field. Balaam beat it to get it back on the road.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of the Lord stood in a narrow path through the vineyards, with walls on both sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the donkey saw the angel of the Lord, it pressed close to the wall, crushing Balaam’s foot against it. So he beat the donkey again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of the Lord moved on ahead and stood in a narrow place where there was no room to turn, either to the right or to the left.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the donkey saw the angel of the Lord, it lay down under Balaam, and he was angry and beat it with his staff.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord opened the donkey’s mouth, and it said to Balaam, “What have I done to you to make you beat me these three times?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam answered the donkey, “You have made a fool of me! If only I had a sword in my hand, I would kill you right now.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The donkey said to Balaam, “Am I not your own donkey, which you have always ridden, to this day? Have I been in the habit of doing this to you?”
“No,” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord opened Balaam’s eyes, and he saw the angel of the Lord standing in the road with his sword drawn. So he bowed low and fell facedown.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord asked him, “Why have you beaten your donkey these three times? I have come here to oppose you because your path is a reckless one before me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The donkey saw me and turned away from me these three times. If it had not turned away, I would certainly have killed you by now, but I would have spared it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to the angel of the Lord, “I have sinned. I did not realize you were standing in the road to oppose me. Now if you are displeased, I will go back.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord said to Balaam, “Go with the men, but speak only what I tell you.” So Balaam went with Balak’s officials.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Balak heard that Balaam was coming, he went out to meet him at the Moabite town on the Arnon border, at the edge of his territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak said to Balaam, “Did I not send you an urgent summons? Why didn’t you come to me? Am I really not able to reward you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Well, I have come to you now,” Balaam replied. “But I can’t say whatever I please. I must speak only what God puts in my mouth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balaam went with Balak to Kiriath Huzoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak sacrificed cattle and sheep, and gave some to Balaam and the officials who were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next morning Balak took Balaam up to Bamoth Baal, and from there he could see the outskirts of the Israelite camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said, “Build me seven altars here, and prepare seven bulls and seven rams for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak did as Balaam said, and the two of them offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balaam said to Balak, “Stay here beside your offering while I go aside. Perhaps the Lord will come to meet with me. Whatever he reveals to me I will tell you.” Then he went off to a barren height.
speaker: Narrator

text: God met with him, and Balaam said, “I have prepared seven altars, and on each altar I have offered a bull and a ram.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord put a word in Balaam’s mouth and said, “Go back to Balak and give him this word.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went back to him and found him standing beside his offering, with all the Moabite officials.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Balaam spoke his message:
“Balak brought me from Aram,
    the king of Moab from the eastern mountains.
‘Come,’ he said, ‘curse Jacob for me;
    come, denounce Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
How can I curse
    those whom God has not cursed?
How can I denounce
    those whom the Lord has not denounced?
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the rocky peaks I see them,
    from the heights I view them.
I see a people who live apart
    and do not consider themselves one of the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can count the dust of Jacob
    or number even a fourth of Israel?
Let me die the death of the righteous,
    and may my final end be like theirs!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak said to Balaam, “What have you done to me? I brought you to curse my enemies, but you have done nothing but bless them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: He answered, “Must I not speak what the Lord puts in my mouth?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balak said to him, “Come with me to another place where you can see them; you will not see them all but only the outskirts of their camp. And from there, curse them for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took him to the field of Zophim on the top of Pisgah, and there he built seven altars and offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to Balak, “Stay here beside your offering while I meet with him over there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord met with Balaam and put a word in his mouth and said, “Go back to Balak and give him this word.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went to him and found him standing beside his offering, with the Moabite officials. Balak asked him, “What did the Lord say?”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
God is not human, that he should lie,
    not a human being, that he should change his mind.
Does he speak and then not act?
    Does he promise and not fulfill?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have received a command to bless;
    he has blessed, and I cannot change it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“No misfortune is seen in Jacob,
    no misery observed in Israel.
The Lord their God is with them;
    the shout of the King is among them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God brought them out of Egypt;
    they have the strength of a wild ox.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is no divination against Jacob,
    no evil omens against Israel.
It will now be said of Jacob
    and of Israel, ‘See what God has done!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people rise like a lioness;
    they rouse themselves like a lion
that does not rest till it devours its prey
    and drinks the blood of its victims.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balak said to Balaam, “Neither curse them at all nor bless them at all!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam answered, “Did I not tell you I must do whatever the Lord says?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balak said to Balaam, “Come, let me take you to another place. Perhaps it will please God to let you curse them for me from there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Balak took Balaam to the top of Peor, overlooking the wasteland.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said, “Build me seven altars here, and prepare seven bulls and seven rams for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak did as Balaam had said, and offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Balaam saw that it pleased the Lord to bless Israel, he did not resort to divination as at other times, but turned his face toward the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Balaam looked out and saw Israel encamped tribe by tribe, the Spirit of God came on him
speaker: Narrator

text:
and he spoke his message:
“The prophecy of Balaam son of Beor,
    the prophecy of one whose eye sees clearly,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the prophecy of one who hears the words of God,
    who sees a vision from the Almighty,
    who falls prostrate, and whose eyes are opened:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How beautiful are your tents, Jacob,
    your dwelling places, Israel!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Like valleys they spread out,
    like gardens beside a river,
like aloes planted by the Lord,
    like cedars beside the waters.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Like a lion they crouch and lie down,
    like a lioness—who dares to rouse them?
“May those who bless you be blessed
    and those who curse you be cursed!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balak’s anger burned against Balaam. He struck his hands together and said to him, “I summoned you to curse my enemies, but you have blessed them these three times.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now leave at once and go home! I said I would reward you handsomely, but the Lord has kept you from being rewarded.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam answered Balak, “Did I not tell the messengers you sent me,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Even if Balak gave me all the silver and gold in his palace, I could not do anything of my own accord, good or bad, to go beyond the command of the Lord—and I must say only what the Lord says’?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I am going back to my people, but come, let me warn you of what this people will do to your people in days to come.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he spoke his message:
“The prophecy of Balaam son of Beor,
    the prophecy of one whose eye sees clearly,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the prophecy of one who hears the words of God,
    who has knowledge from the Most High,
who sees a vision from the Almighty,
    who falls prostrate, and whose eyes are opened:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
A ruler will come out of Jacob
    and destroy the survivors of the city.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Balaam saw Amalek and spoke his message:
“Amalek was first among the nations,
    but their end will be utter destruction.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
yet you Kenites will be destroyed
    when Ashur takes you captive.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he spoke his message:
“Alas! Who can live when God does this?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Then Balaam got up and returned home, and Balak went his own way.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Israel was staying in Shittim, the men began to indulge in sexual immorality with Moabite women,
speaker: Narrator

text: who invited them to the sacrifices to their gods. The people ate the sacrificial meal and bowed down before these gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel yoked themselves to the Baal of Peor. And the Lord’s anger burned against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Take all the leaders of these people, kill them and expose them in broad daylight before the Lord, so that the Lord’s fierce anger may turn away from Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses said to Israel’s judges, “Each of you must put to death those of your people who have yoked themselves to the Baal of Peor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then an Israelite man brought into the camp a Midianite woman right before the eyes of Moses and the whole assembly of Israel while they were weeping at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Phinehas son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron, the priest, saw this, he left the assembly, took a spear in his hand
speaker: Narrator

text: and followed the Israelite into the tent. He drove the spear into both of them, right through the Israelite man and into the woman’s stomach. Then the plague against the Israelites was stopped;
speaker: Narrator

text: but those who died in the plague numbered 24,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Phinehas son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron, the priest, has turned my anger away from the Israelites. Since he was as zealous for my honor among them as I am, I did not put an end to them in my zeal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore tell him I am making my covenant of peace with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He and his descendants will have a covenant of a lasting priesthood, because he was zealous for the honor of his God and made atonement for the Israelites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the Israelite who was killed with the Midianite woman was Zimri son of Salu, the leader of a Simeonite family.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the name of the Midianite woman who was put to death was Kozbi daughter of Zur, a tribal chief of a Midianite family.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Treat the Midianites as enemies and kill them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They treated you as enemies when they deceived you in the Peor incident involving their sister Kozbi, the daughter of a Midianite leader, the woman who was killed when the plague came as a result of that incident.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After the plague the Lord said to Moses and Eleazar son of Aaron, the priest,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take a census of the whole Israelite community by families—all those twenty years old or more who are able to serve in the army of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So on the plains of Moab by the Jordan across from Jericho, Moses and Eleazar the priest spoke with them and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Take a census of the men twenty years old or more, as the Lord commanded Moses.”
These were the Israelites who came out of Egypt:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
through Hezron, the Hezronite clan;
through Karmi, the Karmite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the clans of Reuben; those numbered were 43,730.
speaker: Narrator

text: The son of Pallu was Eliab,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the sons of Eliab were Nemuel, Dathan and Abiram. The same Dathan and Abiram were the community officials who rebelled against Moses and Aaron and were among Korah’s followers when they rebelled against the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth opened its mouth and swallowed them along with Korah, whose followers died when the fire devoured the 250 men. And they served as a warning sign.
speaker: Narrator

text: The line of Korah, however, did not die out.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
through Zerah, the Zerahite clan;
through Shaul, the Shaulite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the clans of Simeon; those numbered were 22,200.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
through Ozni, the Oznite clan;
through Eri, the Erite clan;
speaker: Narrator

text:
through Arodi, the Arodite clan;
through Areli, the Arelite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the clans of Gad; those numbered were 40,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: Er and Onan were sons of Judah, but they died in Canaan.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text: These were the clans of Judah; those numbered were 76,500.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
through Jashub, the Jashubite clan;
through Shimron, the Shimronite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the clans of Issachar; those numbered were 64,300.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: These were the clans of Zebulun; those numbered were 60,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Joseph by their clans through Manasseh and Ephraim were:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
through Asriel, the Asrielite clan;
through Shechem, the Shechemite clan;
speaker: Narrator

text:
through Shemida, the Shemidaite clan;
through Hepher, the Hepherite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Zelophehad son of Hepher had no sons; he had only daughters, whose names were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milkah and Tirzah.)
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the clans of Manasseh; those numbered were 52,700.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
These were the descendants of Shuthelah:
through Eran, the Eranite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the clans of Ephraim; those numbered were 32,500.
These were the descendants of Joseph by their clans.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
through Shupham, the Shuphamite clan;
through Hupham, the Huphamite clan.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: These were the clans of Benjamin; those numbered were 45,600.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the descendants of Dan by their clans:
through Shuham, the Shuhamite clan.
These were the clans of Dan:
speaker: Narrator

text: All of them were Shuhamite clans; and those numbered were 64,400.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text: (Asher had a daughter named Serah.)
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the clans of Asher; those numbered were 53,400.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
through Jezer, the Jezerite clan;
through Shillem, the Shillemite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the clans of Naphtali; those numbered were 45,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of the men of Israel was 601,730.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “The land is to be allotted to them as an inheritance based on the number of names.
speaker: Narrator

text: To a larger group give a larger inheritance, and to a smaller group a smaller one; each is to receive its inheritance according to the number of those listed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be sure that the land is distributed by lot. What each group inherits will be according to the names for its ancestral tribe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each inheritance is to be distributed by lot among the larger and smaller groups.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
These also were Levite clans:
the Libnite clan,
the Hebronite clan,
the Mahlite clan,
the Mushite clan,
the Korahite clan.
(Kohath was the forefather of Amram;
speaker: Narrator

text: the name of Amram’s wife was Jochebed, a descendant of Levi, who was born to the Levites in Egypt. To Amram she bore Aaron, Moses and their sister Miriam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron was the father of Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Nadab and Abihu died when they made an offering before the Lord with unauthorized fire.)
speaker: Narrator

text: All the male Levites a month old or more numbered 23,000. They were not counted along with the other Israelites because they received no inheritance among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the ones counted by Moses and Eleazar the priest when they counted the Israelites on the plains of Moab by the Jordan across from Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not one of them was among those counted by Moses and Aaron the priest when they counted the Israelites in the Desert of Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord had told those Israelites they would surely die in the wilderness, and not one of them was left except Caleb son of Jephunneh and Joshua son of Nun.
speaker: Narrator

text: The daughters of Zelophehad son of Hepher, the son of Gilead, the son of Makir, the son of Manasseh, belonged to the clans of Manasseh son of Joseph. The names of the daughters were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milkah and Tirzah. They came forward
speaker: Narrator

text: and stood before Moses, Eleazar the priest, the leaders and the whole assembly at the entrance to the tent of meeting and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Our father died in the wilderness. He was not among Korah’s followers, who banded together against the Lord, but he died for his own sin and left no sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why should our father’s name disappear from his clan because he had no son? Give us property among our father’s relatives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses brought their case before the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Lord said to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: “What Zelophehad’s daughters are saying is right. You must certainly give them property as an inheritance among their father’s relatives and give their father’s inheritance to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to the Israelites, ‘If a man dies and leaves no son, give his inheritance to his daughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he has no daughter, give his inheritance to his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he has no brothers, give his inheritance to his father’s brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: If his father had no brothers, give his inheritance to the nearest relative in his clan, that he may possess it. This is to have the force of law for the Israelites, as the Lord commanded Moses.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go up this mountain in the Abarim Range and see the land I have given the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: After you have seen it, you too will be gathered to your people, as your brother Aaron was,
speaker: Narrator

text: for when the community rebelled at the waters in the Desert of Zin, both of you disobeyed my command to honor me as holy before their eyes.” (These were the waters of Meribah Kadesh, in the Desert of Zin.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: “May the Lord, the God who gives breath to all living things, appoint someone over this community
speaker: Narrator

text: to go out and come in before them, one who will lead them out and bring them in, so the Lord’s people will not be like sheep without a shepherd.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said to Moses, “Take Joshua son of Nun, a man in whom is the spirit of leadership, and lay your hand on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have him stand before Eleazar the priest and the entire assembly and commission him in their presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give him some of your authority so the whole Israelite community will obey him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to stand before Eleazar the priest, who will obtain decisions for him by inquiring of the Urim before the Lord. At his command he and the entire community of the Israelites will go out, and at his command they will come in.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses did as the Lord commanded him. He took Joshua and had him stand before Eleazar the priest and the whole assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he laid his hands on him and commissioned him, as the Lord instructed through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Give this command to the Israelites and say to them: ‘Make sure that you present to me at the appointed time my food offerings, as an aroma pleasing to me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to them: ‘This is the food offering you are to present to the Lord: two lambs a year old without defect, as a regular burnt offering each day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Offer one lamb in the morning and the other at twilight,
speaker: Narrator

text: together with a grain offering of a tenth of an ephah of the finest flour mixed with a quarter of a hin of oil from pressed olives.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the regular burnt offering instituted at Mount Sinai as a pleasing aroma, a food offering presented to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The accompanying drink offering is to be a quarter of a hin of fermented drink with each lamb. Pour out the drink offering to the Lord at the sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: Offer the second lamb at twilight, along with the same kind of grain offering and drink offering that you offer in the morning. This is a food offering, an aroma pleasing to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the Sabbath day, make an offering of two lambs a year old without defect, together with its drink offering and a grain offering of two-tenths of an ephah of the finest flour mixed with olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the burnt offering for every Sabbath, in addition to the regular burnt offering and its drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the first of every month, present to the Lord a burnt offering of two young bulls, one ram and seven male lambs a year old, all without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: With each bull there is to be a grain offering of three-tenths of an ephah of the finest flour mixed with oil; with the ram, a grain offering of two-tenths of an ephah of the finest flour mixed with oil;
speaker: Narrator

text: and with each lamb, a grain offering of a tenth of an ephah of the finest flour mixed with oil. This is for a burnt offering, a pleasing aroma, a food offering presented to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: With each bull there is to be a drink offering of half a hin of wine; with the ram, a third of a hin; and with each lamb, a quarter of a hin. This is the monthly burnt offering to be made at each new moon during the year.
speaker: Narrator

text: Besides the regular burnt offering with its drink offering, one male goat is to be presented to the Lord as a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the fourteenth day of the first month the Lord’s Passover is to be held.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fifteenth day of this month there is to be a festival; for seven days eat bread made without yeast.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day hold a sacred assembly and do no regular work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Present to the Lord a food offering consisting of a burnt offering of two young bulls, one ram and seven male lambs a year old, all without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: With each bull offer a grain offering of three-tenths of an ephah of the finest flour mixed with oil; with the ram, two-tenths;
speaker: Narrator

text: and with each of the seven lambs, one-tenth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Include one male goat as a sin offering to make atonement for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Offer these in addition to the regular morning burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way present the food offering every day for seven days as an aroma pleasing to the Lord; it is to be offered in addition to the regular burnt offering and its drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day hold a sacred assembly and do no regular work.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the day of firstfruits, when you present to the Lord an offering of new grain during the Festival of Weeks, hold a sacred assembly and do no regular work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Present a burnt offering of two young bulls, one ram and seven male lambs a year old as an aroma pleasing to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: With each bull there is to be a grain offering of three-tenths of an ephah of the finest flour mixed with oil; with the ram, two-tenths;
speaker: Narrator

text: and with each of the seven lambs, one-tenth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Include one male goat to make atonement for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Offer these together with their drink offerings, in addition to the regular burnt offering and its grain offering. Be sure the animals are without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the first day of the seventh month hold a sacred assembly and do no regular work. It is a day for you to sound the trumpets.
speaker: Narrator

text: As an aroma pleasing to the Lord, offer a burnt offering of one young bull, one ram and seven male lambs a year old, all without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the bull offer a grain offering of three-tenths of an ephah of the finest flour mixed with olive oil; with the ram, two-tenths;
speaker: Narrator

text: and with each of the seven lambs, one-tenth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Include one male goat as a sin offering to make atonement for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are in addition to the monthly and daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and drink offerings as specified. They are food offerings presented to the Lord, a pleasing aroma.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the tenth day of this seventh month hold a sacred assembly. You must deny yourselves and do no work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Present as an aroma pleasing to the Lord a burnt offering of one young bull, one ram and seven male lambs a year old, all without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the bull offer a grain offering of three-tenths of an ephah of the finest flour mixed with oil; with the ram, two-tenths;
speaker: Narrator

text: and with each of the seven lambs, one-tenth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Include one male goat as a sin offering, in addition to the sin offering for atonement and the regular burnt offering with its grain offering, and their drink offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the fifteenth day of the seventh month, hold a sacred assembly and do no regular work. Celebrate a festival to the Lord for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Present as an aroma pleasing to the Lord a food offering consisting of a burnt offering of thirteen young bulls, two rams and fourteen male lambs a year old, all without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: With each of the thirteen bulls offer a grain offering of three-tenths of an ephah of the finest flour mixed with oil; with each of the two rams, two-tenths;
speaker: Narrator

text: and with each of the fourteen lambs, one-tenth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Include one male goat as a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain offering and drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the second day offer twelve young bulls, two rams and fourteen male lambs a year old, all without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the bulls, rams and lambs, offer their grain offerings and drink offerings according to the number specified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Include one male goat as a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain offering, and their drink offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the third day offer eleven bulls, two rams and fourteen male lambs a year old, all without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the bulls, rams and lambs, offer their grain offerings and drink offerings according to the number specified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Include one male goat as a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain offering and drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the fourth day offer ten bulls, two rams and fourteen male lambs a year old, all without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the bulls, rams and lambs, offer their grain offerings and drink offerings according to the number specified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Include one male goat as a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain offering and drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the fifth day offer nine bulls, two rams and fourteen male lambs a year old, all without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the bulls, rams and lambs, offer their grain offerings and drink offerings according to the number specified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Include one male goat as a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain offering and drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the sixth day offer eight bulls, two rams and fourteen male lambs a year old, all without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the bulls, rams and lambs, offer their grain offerings and drink offerings according to the number specified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Include one male goat as a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain offering and drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the seventh day offer seven bulls, two rams and fourteen male lambs a year old, all without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the bulls, rams and lambs, offer their grain offerings and drink offerings according to the number specified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Include one male goat as a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain offering and drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the eighth day hold a closing special assembly and do no regular work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Present as an aroma pleasing to the Lord a food offering consisting of a burnt offering of one bull, one ram and seven male lambs a year old, all without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the bull, the ram and the lambs, offer their grain offerings and drink offerings according to the number specified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Include one male goat as a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain offering and drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘In addition to what you vow and your freewill offerings, offer these to the Lord at your appointed festivals: your burnt offerings, grain offerings, drink offerings and fellowship offerings.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told the Israelites all that the Lord commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the heads of the tribes of Israel: “This is what the Lord commands:
speaker: Narrator

text: When a man makes a vow to the Lord or takes an oath to obligate himself by a pledge, he must not break his word but must do everything he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a young woman still living in her father’s household makes a vow to the Lord or obligates herself by a pledge
speaker: Narrator

text: and her father hears about her vow or pledge but says nothing to her, then all her vows and every pledge by which she obligated herself will stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if her father forbids her when he hears about it, none of her vows or the pledges by which she obligated herself will stand; the Lord will release her because her father has forbidden her.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If she marries after she makes a vow or after her lips utter a rash promise by which she obligates herself
speaker: Narrator

text: and her husband hears about it but says nothing to her, then her vows or the pledges by which she obligated herself will stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if her husband forbids her when he hears about it, he nullifies the vow that obligates her or the rash promise by which she obligates herself, and the Lord will release her.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Any vow or obligation taken by a widow or divorced woman will be binding on her.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a woman living with her husband makes a vow or obligates herself by a pledge under oath
speaker: Narrator

text: and her husband hears about it but says nothing to her and does not forbid her, then all her vows or the pledges by which she obligated herself will stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if her husband nullifies them when he hears about them, then none of the vows or pledges that came from her lips will stand. Her husband has nullified them, and the Lord will release her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her husband may confirm or nullify any vow she makes or any sworn pledge to deny herself.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if her husband says nothing to her about it from day to day, then he confirms all her vows or the pledges binding on her. He confirms them by saying nothing to her when he hears about them.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, he nullifies them some time after he hears about them, then he must bear the consequences of her wrongdoing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the regulations the Lord gave Moses concerning relationships between a man and his wife, and between a father and his young daughter still living at home.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take vengeance on the Midianites for the Israelites. After that, you will be gathered to your people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses said to the people, “Arm some of your men to go to war against the Midianites so that they may carry out the Lord’s vengeance on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Send into battle a thousand men from each of the tribes of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So twelve thousand men armed for battle, a thousand from each tribe, were supplied from the clans of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses sent them into battle, a thousand from each tribe, along with Phinehas son of Eleazar, the priest, who took with him articles from the sanctuary and the trumpets for signaling.
speaker: Narrator

text: They fought against Midian, as the Lord commanded Moses, and killed every man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Among their victims were Evi, Rekem, Zur, Hur and Reba—the five kings of Midian. They also killed Balaam son of Beor with the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites captured the Midianite women and children and took all the Midianite herds, flocks and goods as plunder.
speaker: Narrator

text: They burned all the towns where the Midianites had settled, as well as all their camps.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took all the plunder and spoils, including the people and animals,
speaker: Narrator

text: and brought the captives, spoils and plunder to Moses and Eleazar the priest and the Israelite assembly at their camp on the plains of Moab, by the Jordan across from Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses, Eleazar the priest and all the leaders of the community went to meet them outside the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was angry with the officers of the army—the commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds—who returned from the battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Have you allowed all the women to live?” he asked them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They were the ones who followed Balaam’s advice and enticed the Israelites to be unfaithful to the Lord in the Peor incident, so that a plague struck the Lord’s people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now kill all the boys. And kill every woman who has slept with a man,
speaker: Narrator

text: but save for yourselves every girl who has never slept with a man.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Anyone who has killed someone or touched someone who was killed must stay outside the camp seven days. On the third and seventh days you must purify yourselves and your captives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Purify every garment as well as everything made of leather, goat hair or wood.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eleazar the priest said to the soldiers who had gone into battle, “This is what is required by the law that the Lord gave Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: Gold, silver, bronze, iron, tin, lead
speaker: Narrator

text: and anything else that can withstand fire must be put through the fire, and then it will be clean. But it must also be purified with the water of cleansing. And whatever cannot withstand fire must be put through that water.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day wash your clothes and you will be clean. Then you may come into the camp.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “You and Eleazar the priest and the family heads of the community are to count all the people and animals that were captured.
speaker: Narrator

text: Divide the spoils equally between the soldiers who took part in the battle and the rest of the community.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the soldiers who fought in the battle, set apart as tribute for the Lord one out of every five hundred, whether people, cattle, donkeys or sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take this tribute from their half share and give it to Eleazar the priest as the Lord’s part.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the Israelites’ half, select one out of every fifty, whether people, cattle, donkeys, sheep or other animals. Give them to the Levites, who are responsible for the care of the Lord’s tabernacle.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Eleazar the priest did as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The plunder remaining from the spoils that the soldiers took was 675,000 sheep,
speaker: Narrator

text: 72,000 cattle,
speaker: Narrator

text: 61,000 donkeys
speaker: Narrator

text: and 32,000 women who had never slept with a man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The half share of those who fought in the battle was:
337,500 sheep,
speaker: Narrator

text: of which the tribute for the Lord was 675;
speaker: Narrator

text: 36,000 cattle, of which the tribute for the Lord was 72;
speaker: Narrator

text: 30,500 donkeys, of which the tribute for the Lord was 61;
speaker: Narrator

text: 16,000 people, of whom the tribute for the Lord was 32.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses gave the tribute to Eleazar the priest as the Lord’s part, as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The half belonging to the Israelites, which Moses set apart from that of the fighting men—
speaker: Narrator

text: the community’s half—was 337,500 sheep,
speaker: Narrator

text: 36,000 cattle,
speaker: Narrator

text: 30,500 donkeys
speaker: Narrator

text: and 16,000 people.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the Israelites’ half, Moses selected one out of every fifty people and animals, as the Lord commanded him, and gave them to the Levites, who were responsible for the care of the Lord’s tabernacle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the officers who were over the units of the army—the commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds—went to Moses
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to him, “Your servants have counted the soldiers under our command, and not one is missing.
speaker: Narrator

text: So we have brought as an offering to the Lord the gold articles each of us acquired—armlets, bracelets, signet rings, earrings and necklaces—to make atonement for ourselves before the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Eleazar the priest accepted from them the gold—all the crafted articles.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the gold from the commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds that Moses and Eleazar presented as a gift to the Lord weighed 16,750 shekels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each soldier had taken plunder for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Eleazar the priest accepted the gold from the commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds and brought it into the tent of meeting as a memorial for the Israelites before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Reubenites and Gadites, who had very large herds and flocks, saw that the lands of Jazer and Gilead were suitable for livestock.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they came to Moses and Eleazar the priest and to the leaders of the community, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Ataroth, Dibon, Jazer, Nimrah, Heshbon, Elealeh, Sebam, Nebo and Beon—
speaker: Narrator

text: the land the Lord subdued before the people of Israel—are suitable for livestock, and your servants have livestock.
speaker: Narrator

text: If we have found favor in your eyes,” they said, “let this land be given to your servants as our possession. Do not make us cross the Jordan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the Gadites and Reubenites, “Should your fellow Israelites go to war while you sit here?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why do you discourage the Israelites from crossing over into the land the Lord has given them?
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what your fathers did when I sent them from Kadesh Barnea to look over the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they went up to the Valley of Eshkol and viewed the land, they discouraged the Israelites from entering the land the Lord had given them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s anger was aroused that day and he swore this oath:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Because they have not followed me wholeheartedly, not one of those who were twenty years old or more when they came up out of Egypt will see the land I promised on oath to Abraham, Isaac and Jacob—
speaker: Narrator

text: not one except Caleb son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite and Joshua son of Nun, for they followed the Lord wholeheartedly.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s anger burned against Israel and he made them wander in the wilderness forty years, until the whole generation of those who had done evil in his sight was gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And here you are, a brood of sinners, standing in the place of your fathers and making the Lord even more angry with Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you turn away from following him, he will again leave all this people in the wilderness, and you will be the cause of their destruction.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they came up to him and said, “We would like to build pens here for our livestock and cities for our women and children.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we will arm ourselves for battle and go ahead of the Israelites until we have brought them to their place. Meanwhile our women and children will live in fortified cities, for protection from the inhabitants of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: We will not return to our homes until each of the Israelites has received their inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: We will not receive any inheritance with them on the other side of the Jordan, because our inheritance has come to us on the east side of the Jordan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to them, “If you will do this—if you will arm yourselves before the Lord for battle
speaker: Narrator

text: and if all of you who are armed cross over the Jordan before the Lord until he has driven his enemies out before him—
speaker: Narrator

text: then when the land is subdued before the Lord, you may return and be free from your obligation to the Lord and to Israel. And this land will be your possession before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if you fail to do this, you will be sinning against the Lord; and you may be sure that your sin will find you out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Build cities for your women and children, and pens for your flocks, but do what you have promised.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Gadites and Reubenites said to Moses, “We your servants will do as our lord commands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our children and wives, our flocks and herds will remain here in the cities of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: But your servants, every man who is armed for battle, will cross over to fight before the Lord, just as our lord says.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses gave orders about them to Eleazar the priest and Joshua son of Nun and to the family heads of the Israelite tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “If the Gadites and Reubenites, every man armed for battle, cross over the Jordan with you before the Lord, then when the land is subdued before you, you must give them the land of Gilead as their possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if they do not cross over with you armed, they must accept their possession with you in Canaan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Gadites and Reubenites answered, “Your servants will do what the Lord has said.
speaker: Narrator

text: We will cross over before the Lord into Canaan armed, but the property we inherit will be on this side of the Jordan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses gave to the Gadites, the Reubenites and the half-tribe of Manasseh son of Joseph the kingdom of Sihon king of the Amorites and the kingdom of Og king of Bashan—the whole land with its cities and the territory around them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Gadites built up Dibon, Ataroth, Aroer,
speaker: Narrator

text: Atroth Shophan, Jazer, Jogbehah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Beth Nimrah and Beth Haran as fortified cities, and built pens for their flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Reubenites rebuilt Heshbon, Elealeh and Kiriathaim,
speaker: Narrator

text: as well as Nebo and Baal Meon (these names were changed) and Sibmah. They gave names to the cities they rebuilt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Makir son of Manasseh went to Gilead, captured it and drove out the Amorites who were there.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses gave Gilead to the Makirites, the descendants of Manasseh, and they settled there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jair, a descendant of Manasseh, captured their settlements and called them Havvoth Jair.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Nobah captured Kenath and its surrounding settlements and called it Nobah after himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here are the stages in the journey of the Israelites when they came out of Egypt by divisions under the leadership of Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the Lord’s command Moses recorded the stages in their journey. This is their journey by stages:
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites set out from Rameses on the fifteenth day of the first month, the day after the Passover. They marched out defiantly in full view of all the Egyptians,
speaker: Narrator

text: who were burying all their firstborn, whom the Lord had struck down among them; for the Lord had brought judgment on their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites left Rameses and camped at Sukkoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Sukkoth and camped at Etham, on the edge of the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Etham, turned back to Pi Hahiroth, to the east of Baal Zephon, and camped near Migdol.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Pi Hahiroth and passed through the sea into the desert, and when they had traveled for three days in the Desert of Etham, they camped at Marah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Marah and went to Elim, where there were twelve springs and seventy palm trees, and they camped there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Elim and camped by the Red Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left the Red Sea and camped in the Desert of Sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left the Desert of Sin and camped at Dophkah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Dophkah and camped at Alush.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Alush and camped at Rephidim, where there was no water for the people to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Rephidim and camped in the Desert of Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left the Desert of Sinai and camped at Kibroth Hattaavah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Kibroth Hattaavah and camped at Hazeroth.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Hazeroth and camped at Rithmah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Rithmah and camped at Rimmon Perez.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Rimmon Perez and camped at Libnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Libnah and camped at Rissah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Rissah and camped at Kehelathah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Kehelathah and camped at Mount Shepher.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Mount Shepher and camped at Haradah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Haradah and camped at Makheloth.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Makheloth and camped at Tahath.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Tahath and camped at Terah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Terah and camped at Mithkah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Mithkah and camped at Hashmonah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Hashmonah and camped at Moseroth.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Moseroth and camped at Bene Jaakan.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Bene Jaakan and camped at Hor Haggidgad.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Hor Haggidgad and camped at Jotbathah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Jotbathah and camped at Abronah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Abronah and camped at Ezion Geber.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Ezion Geber and camped at Kadesh, in the Desert of Zin.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Kadesh and camped at Mount Hor, on the border of Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the Lord’s command Aaron the priest went up Mount Hor, where he died on the first day of the fifth month of the fortieth year after the Israelites came out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron was a hundred and twenty-three years old when he died on Mount Hor.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Canaanite king of Arad, who lived in the Negev of Canaan, heard that the Israelites were coming.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Mount Hor and camped at Zalmonah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Zalmonah and camped at Punon.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Punon and camped at Oboth.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Oboth and camped at Iye Abarim, on the border of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Iye Abarim and camped at Dibon Gad.
speaker: Narrator

text: They left Dibon Gad and camped at Almon Diblathaim.
speaker: Narrator
